She left them groaning and headed to the galley, thinking coffee sounded like a good idea. There was a metal cup sitting upside down in the drying rack, a blue tin cups with the white flecks. The outside of it had been dipped in rubber for use on submarines. Even when well-washed, the cups always added a particular piquant of metal and oil to the coffee. The one in the dish rack was relatively clean, just retaining the usual semi-permanent brown ring stains.

The coffee in the pot had been on the warmer for hours. Maybe days. She poured it into her cup and added a couple of scoops of sugar. The taste was foul, like what she always imagined â€œsweet crudeâ€ must taste like. Her taste buds rebelled, but the rest of her body knew better, and she felt an immediate wash of relief from the fatigue beginning to plague her.

Their situation was dire, but she was feeling better. If being flooded and bottomed had been the worst thing that happened today, she would have been upset. But somehow their relative safety right now compared to where they had been an hour before â€” when they were slowly sinking over a bottomless hole â€” made Percy feel surprisingly relaxed. Relaxed enough to enjoy a cup of burnt coffee at least.

Percy found another relatively clean tin cup behind the rails of the dish cabinet and filled it with coffee. She brought it to Hemi at the navigation station.

Hemi took the cup and held it to his lips blowing the acid smell off the surface. His glasses steamed up. â€œDoes Chips have a handle on the leak?â€

â€œEh. Itâ€™s under deep fucking water in the hold now. Sheâ€™s going to have to dive down there to weld it.â€

â€œUnpleasant.â€

â€œThatâ€™s one fucking word for it.â€

â€œEven if we get it sealed,â€ said Hemi, â€œeven if we can manage to pump out, even if we get to the surface, things do not look good. I looked at the chart, and we are approximately nowhere at the moment. And we have no fuel or battery remaining to speak of.â€

â€œStillâ€™d rather be nowhere on the surface than sunk on the bottom of somewhere â€” in this case that â€˜somewhereâ€™ being a fucking rarely-charted and never-visited undersea mountain.â€

â€œWe are in a situation where we need to overcome a whole series of challenges, each in their particular order. I am just trying to get ahead of the problem.â€

â€œOK Hemi, you do the thinking ahead. You let me know if Iâ€™m not considering something that impacts our future survivability. Otherwise, I need to focus on surviving our situation right now. And that currently means getting some of this foul black water out of my boat. Right?â€

Hemi nodded.

â€œOK. Back to the cargo hold I go then.â€

âŸ

In the cargo hold, Bastian and Gregory were laying out the heavy cloth-covered hoses down the center of the space and hooking them up to portable electric bilge pumps the size of small refrigerators. Multiple black hoses and thick electrical cables snaked across the floor grating making navigating the space treacherous.

Owen had his own electric pump â€” a smaller one that pumped air â€” down at the edge of the black lake, and he was feeding an air hose to Chips who was wearing a diving mask connected to the hose. She was kicking to keep her head above water while holding up a welding stick with one hand. The welding stick was connected by its own lines to the welding rig propped next to the pump at the edge of the lake and powered by yet more heavy electrical cables running up the deck of the cargo hold. Chocks kept the wheels of the rig from rolling into the water.

Chips dove down, and there was a quiet moment before a hot blue light lit up the surface of the water from below, wavered for a moment, and then died away. This repeated a few times before Chipsâ€™ head broke back through the surface. She ripped off the diving mask. â€œOwen! I need another fuckinâ€™ piece of steel plate, and â€” fuck it â€” another brace too.â€

â€œAlright!â€ called the kid from the shore where the water lapped at the toes of his boots. Owen was wearing the same greasy-slick rubber waders Chips had had on earlier. He selected some metal bits from a pile of scraps on the grating next to the welding rig and waded into the cloying bilge to hand them to Chips.

Every sound in the cargo hold traversed from one exposed steel inner side of the pressure hull to the other, so everything was heard three times. That was normal, and Captain Percy was used to it. But the mass of water filling one end of the cargo hold changed the sound of the space. It ate at her instinctual sense that her boat was far from being healthy. It was hard to pin down precisely how it changed. It sounded like a room dominated by an athletic swimming pool. It was a quality of sound that should never be heard on a submarine.

She sipped her coffee and watched Chips dive again with the steel plates in one hand. More blue light from under the water. Percy had an idea to go and track down a meter stick and prop it in the water, so they could all see when the water started to lower. But then thought better of it, considering the strong possibility of the water quickly rising over the top of the stick.

Instead she helped Gregory and Bastian get the bilge hoses connected to the trim tanks and got them cranking. The hoses inflated with the pressure of the water running up the gentle grade from the pumps. She could hear it sloshing into the empty trim tanks, and the sound of it echoed between the hull walls.

âŸ

The next time Chips was on the shore trying to find a particular patch piece she wanted from the scrap pile, Percy took the diving mask from her and waded into the water to inspect the damage personally. The water was the freezing cold and never-varying temperature of deep ocean water. It had picked up an unpleasant array of smells: a mix of petrochemicals and solvents, refuse, and old grease â€” the stuff that always contaminated a shipâ€™s bilge â€” but that odor was strengthened to a nausea-inducing level by the sheer volume of water.

Plunging her head through the opaque boundary of the waterâ€™s surface, Percy could see the damage was bad. As Chips had said earlier: it wasnâ€™t one big split in the in the metal, it was a long string of short side-by-side cracks running in a line up a massive convex dent where the hull had been rammed. The thick steel of the hull had been bent to an astonishing degree, deformed without massive failure in a way that only high-tensile steel could be. But even steel could be pushed only so far without splitting.

She put her hand out in front of her mask, holding it over the cracks, and she could feel the onrush of the icy water against her warm flesh. Much welding was still required. Chipsâ€™ patches were pieces of curved steel that she would weld into place over the cracks. Chips was no expert at underwater welding, the welds were globulous and imprecise. It was starting to look like a mess, but nobody else aboard could do better.

Back out of the water, she stood shivering and dripping oily droplets that clung together in fatty globs on the floor grating. Percy always thought of herself as pretty tough. But in many ways Chips, with her foul language and bad attitude, was a lot tougher. Chips had never even mentioned the temperature of the water.

With the extra bilge pumps running, Captain Percy let Gregory and Bastian go stumble up to their racks to make another attempt at getting some sleep. And indeed, they slept through the next six hours or so of work while she, Owen, and Hemi did whatever they could to help Chips get the hull welded back together. Since only one person could weld at a time, Percy, Hemi, and Owen found themselves standing around smoking and drinking coffee more than actually working, so Percy eventually sent Hemi and Owen to their racks too.

She needed sleep more than anyone. But she knew she would not be able to. Maybe once they got to the surface, but that seemed far off now â€” both physically and temporally. She smoked up cigarillo after cup of coffee after cigarillo. When Chips needed something she was there, but mostly Chips had her own method and did not want help. When Chips disappeared below the surface it became totally silent in the cargo hold. Percy looked at her watch â€” time had fallen to its knees and crawled forward only with desperate and gasping heaves. It took her more than an hour to realize that the water level had receded a bit, leaving an greasy black line on the pressure hull indicating its high-water mark.

Percy allowed herself some small amount of hope.

The receding water level was everything. The boat did not need power, or the high-pressure air system, or a running motor to reach the surface â€” all she needed was that water level to recede, physics would take care of everything else. The way it was currently set, the boat wanted to float. It was merely being pinned down by a massive black liquid weight.

She waited for Chips to raise her head above the surface again. â€œChips! The water level is dropping!â€ Percy shouted to her with one hand cupped to her mouth, while pointing at the black line of grit marked on the pressure hull.

â€œAh fuckinâ€™ sure. With the fuckinâ€™ quilt of patches Iâ€™ve laid down itâ€™s about fuckinâ€™ time.â€

â€œI have to go up to the control room â€” thereâ€™s really no way to know when weâ€™ll get buoyant again, and someone has to be there if we do.â€

â€œAye!â€ Chips huffed. She waved a hand at Percy and disappeared back under the dark surface.

âŸ

As Captain Percy passed through the crew quarters she shook the kid Owen awake again. â€œI have to go to the control room. Go down and watch Chips and make sure she doesnâ€™t fucking die.â€

Owen didnâ€™t say anything but resignedly rolled out of his rack to his feet, and rubbed his eyes before stumbling toward the cargo hold.

Percy climbed to the control room and sat at one of the maneuvering stations with the familiar array of dials spread out in front of her. The readings had not changed at all since she last left them, for the obvious reason that they had not moved. She took in the reading from each gauge separately, adding it to her holistic picture of the situation her boat was in. But she was not learning anything new.

It suddenly occurred to her that the gauges were the wrong place to look for more input about the status of the boat. She would know the boat was rising before any of the gauges showed it. The water was being drained out so slowly that it was not like the boat would just pop off the bottom. She would feel the slight incline it had taken on as it had settled into the bottom come off first. The boat righting itself would be the first indication it was rising, and she would not need gauges to know that was happening.

She returned to her feet, fished her control-room cigarillo pack from its nook in the wall and lit up. With nothing important to look at, she started pacing back and forth. How long now? She looked at her watch, but realized immediately that that particular gauge was no longer important either.

She glanced over at the control gauges despite herself. This time, just as she did, she saw the angle-of-the-boat gauge waver slightly back and forth in its little glass tube. Ah! She was wrong. The gauges might know first! Seconds later she did feel it. The deck under her feet changed inclination slightly. She reached up and grabbed a strap, and then the whole boat slowly rolled a couple of degrees towards level, shaking off its lethargic repose. But rising from a dead weight on the bottom of the sea was all she did. The boat hung there, relatively evenly trimmed, but the bulk of its weight remained supported by the bottom.

â€œThe trim tanks!â€ Percy remembered they had been pumping bilge water into them, but that water was still physically inside the Prospect. She looked at the ballast control panel. The gauge for the high-pressure air showed the system was severely depleted after their ballast blows. But there was still some residual pressure in the system, and the trim tanks were quite small compared to the big ballast and fuel tanks. She reached to the valve on the ballast panel that would blow bilge water out of the trim tanks and opened it.

There was the usual loud hiss, Percy counted a beat, and then the stern of the boat jumped off the bottom, followed quickly by the bow. The depth-under-keel gauge snapped up to two meters. She could hear suddenly-wakened crew members cursing loudly up at her from the crew quarters. She grabbed the boat PA mic, â€œgood morning motherfuckers! We have positive fucking buoyancy.â€

âŸ

The sensation of moving up instead of down felt oddly terrific. A relief in the change of environmental accelerations that only someone who has acutely attuned themselves to three-dimensional space would recognize.

As soon as Percy had blown out the trim tanks, there was no stopping the Prospect. It was a slow rise, weighted down by the tons of extra weight in water still sloshing around in the cargo hold â€” nothing like the violent rise that an emergency blow would illicit had the boat been functioning normally â€” but they were steadily moving upward.

Hemi popped up in the control room and stood watching the gauges, smiling a quiet smile of intellectual and mechanical satisfaction.

â€œHemi, donâ€™t just stand there like a giant fucking cow,â€ Percy said to him, â€œsit at the controls and make sure nothing stupid happens.â€

Hemi lowered himself into the planes control chair while already turning the dive plane wheel to achieve a more controlled angle of rise.

Percy balanced the trim tanks to keep them as level as possible. â€œKeep the bow slightly down Hemi, otherwise all that water still in the cargo hold is going to wash right back to the engine room.â€

A banging and cursing came up to them from the crew quarters, and a second later Chips climbed into the control room, leaving a small puddle of black water at the base of the ladder, and a thin trail of the foul stuff behind her as she stepped up to Percy. She was holding a length of steel bracing pipe in her hand.

â€œYa gaping and pustulated fucking asshole! Ya almost killed me! What fucking stupid idea came to your impenetrable head to blow the trim tanks with no warning? I was fuckinâ€™ washed half-way down the fucking boat!â€

â€œBack off Chips. I gotta deal with surfacing my boat. We can talk about proper emergency procedures later,â€ Percy replied to Chips, trying to keep her voice calm.

â€œYa fuck yourself and your fucking proper procedures. Iâ€™m talking about my fucking life you fucking swollen and carbuncled head of a syphilitic cock.â€ Chips raised the pipe and pointed it at Percy.

Percy didnâ€™t even look at Chips, instead keeping her eyes on the depth gauge that was steadily showing the boat coming shallower. â€œPut that pipe down Chips.â€

Chips snapped. She rushed at Percy taking the piece of pipe in a long swinging arc across the control room, just missing Hemiâ€™s head but connecting with Captain Percyâ€™s stomach. Percy doubled over immediately and fell to the cold metal of the deck.

Hemi was out of his seat a second later, and had Chipsâ€™ forearms taut in his huge fists, like bracing on the cables of a massive suspension bridge.

Percy was not down long. She got up to one knee before she fired Chips. â€œYouâ€™re off the boat,â€ Percy said quietly between gasping breaths. â€œWe get to a port, you take your gear with you when you get off, and never again befoul my boat with your black fungal attitude.â€

â€œYa? Fuck you, you vegetatively stupid sow. Iâ€™ll fucking be asleep in my rack while your fucking rusting shithole of a boat sinks around you. I donâ€™t fucking care anymore. Iâ€™d rather die than save your bulbous fucking ass one more time.â€

Hemi was steering Chips towards the hatch down out of the control room. He had to let her arms go for her to get down the ladder, though he kept the piece of pipe she had been holding. Hemi and Percy could hear her smashing and cursing her way forward to the crew quarters.

â€œWe all need rest Sylvia,â€ said Hemi.

â€œI need it more than anyone, but you donâ€™t see me swinging pipes at people.â€

Hemi nodded quietly. But he knew Chips was right on two counts: blowing the trim tanks without warning was incredibly dangerous. And they would never get to a port without Chipsâ€™ continuous help to patch the leaking hull.

2. The Gnat

The Prospect rose slowly. It tilted a little on one axis then the other as Captain Percy adjusted the trim of the tanks. But more or less the boat rose straight up since they didnâ€™t have the motors running and it was being lifted by buoyancy alone.

Percy and Hemi watched the depth gauge slowly roll itself backwards, up past their test depth, up into what Percy would normally consider safe operating depth, then periscope depth, and then the sail broke through the surface. Those in the crew quarters could feel the boat bob like a cork to the surface, and at that they let out a small cheer that echoed to the control room from the depths of the boat. They arrived moments later at the bottom of the ladder to the control room, obviously expecting to go out on deck.

At first, Captain Percy was not even going to think about allowing that. Years of experience had reinforced the routine that the first action on surfacing a sub was to scan around with the periscope, if not the radar. There was always a chance that the only safe move was to dive right back down. But she fought back this instinct within herself â€” there was nothing on the surface that could be more dangerous than attempting to dive her damaged boat again. She looked down at her crew â€” minus Chips â€” and waved them up through the control room.

Owen, with his scrawny youthful energy, led the way and charged up the ladder, struggled with the tightly closed and somewhat rusted hatch-seal wheel for a moment before squeaking it open, and pushing the hatch up with a pop as the slight variation in pressure equalized.

Daylight poured down through the hatch into the control room below. With it came cool air in motion. It was air that smelled of the open sea instead of the stench of warm human bodies, oil, and diesel exhaust. The crew followed Owen out onto the bridge of the sail.

It was a cool, breezy day. Gray clouds hung low overhead, and there was a mild chop on the water. Owen hopped over the fairing and down the rungs on the side of the sail to the main deck and ran up and down it shrieking like a small child.

After a few minutes of just enjoying the surface air, Percy got back to the situation at hand. â€œHemi, you were looking at the charts: who controls this part of the surface these days?â€ Percy asked.

â€œHmm. Perhaps the Western Federated Provinces? At least, they did the last time I looked at a Territorial Authorities map. But that was more than a year ago.â€

â€œThose assholes are bad fucking news, and have no tolerance for surface transports â€” even ones that have papers,â€ put in Bastian. â€œWe should not stay here.â€

â€œWe would be on our way right fucking nowâ€¦ if we had any fuel or power,â€ Percy said, â€œthat lovely sound you hear of gentle waves smacking against our hull is the sound of a ship not moving. Weâ€™re dead in the water, and weâ€™re still a bit fucked folks.â€

â€œOwen!â€ she called down to the deck, â€œcome back up here, we have to get back to work.â€ As he ran over and climbed back up the side of the sail she laid out their next steps. â€œHemi, get down to the navigation chart and see if thereâ€™s any hope of any place we could limp to with what little charge we have left on the battery.â€

â€œBastian, get on the radio and see if you can raise anyone on the Independent Operators frequency. Maybe weâ€™ll get extraordinarily lucky and find some help from someone who wonâ€™t ask too many questions.â€

â€œOr try to sink us,â€ Bastian added.

â€œYa. If you do raise anyone, for fuckâ€™s sake donâ€™t talk to them â€” donâ€™t tell them anything. Just come get me and Iâ€™ll try to gauge their reliability myself.â€

â€œSure Capt,â€ said Bastian.

â€œGregoryâ€¦ Iâ€™m starving, want to see if you can get something going in the galley?â€

â€œSounds good.â€

â€œAnd put a new pot of coffee on too. The shit in there now has been on that burner so long it looks like bunker fuel.â€

They climbed back down into the control room, but left the hatch open and for the next few hours a blessed breeze blew through, and occasional tendrils of sea air reached as far into the submarine as the crew quarters.

âŸ

Inside, Captain Percy joined Hemi at the navigation table.

â€œThe most pressing problem,â€ said Hemi not even waiting for her to ask, â€œis the batteries are nearly entirely depleted. Even running extremely judiciously, we have a range of a few nautical miles at best.â€ He used a compass to draw a dotted line around their position showing what was within range. It was a completely barren section of the chart in the middle of the ocean. It was nowhere.

â€œNot even close huh? Well, that just leaves us with the less than ideal option of accepting help from someone.â€

â€œMost who pass in these neglected waters are not much inclined to help those they do not know.â€

â€œWeâ€™ll just have to hope we donâ€™t meet most folks then.â€

She took a couple of steps back to look up through the hatch into the control room and see how Bastian was doing with his effort to achieve that goal. He had one stick-like arm up in the air, adjusting some dials on the radio mounted in the ceiling of the control room. His other hand held the mic that was attached by a curling cloth-covered wire to the radio. He was giving out mayday requests on a couple of different frequencies known to be monitored by other independent shipping operators like themselves â€” both legitimate cargo haulers and smugglers. Those frequencies were also often monitored by Authority vessels that might be engaged in policing shipping and transport traffic through their territorial control areas.

â€œAnything Bastian?â€

â€œFucking nothing. Nothing good or bad. This is one voided piece of open ocean you surfaced us in.â€

â€œAlright. Iâ€™ll check sonar and radar. Maybe someoneâ€™s listening who just isnâ€™t interested in responding.â€

She stepped over to the sonar station and lifted the headphones over her ears. Without bothering to sit, she turned the directional control wheel with one hand, slowly back and forth, scanning for the sound of anything made by humans. A minor benefit of being dead in the water was they were not making any noise themselves. She could hear even the small waves against the hull of the Prospect. It was a rare pleasure to have such clean and clear sound on sonar. But for all that silence, there was nothing to hear.

The passive sonar was safer to use than the radar because it did not send out any signal that could be detected. You just listened with what were essentially underwater microphones for the sound any other vessel might be making. It also had the advantage that it could be used while submerged. Radar, on the other hand, could only be used while they were on the surface, and it sent out a big loud radio beacon that could be seen by any other ship with a radar unit â€” basically all of them. If there were any ships out there, the signal would bounce back to the Prospect and they would know the location. But any other ship in range could detect the radar signal and also know the precise location of the Prospect. Generally when Percy used radar, her habit was to dive soon afterwards.

In this case, she thought turning on the radar was worth the risk. But the radar sweep rolled twice around the display showing a completely empty scope. There was nothing for miles in every direction. She left it scanning and eased herself into the sonar station chair and tried to get comfortable.

For the next few hours she chain-smoked and listened to the emptiness of the ocean around them on the passive sonar. It was a mind-numbing task trying to pick out a signal from the muted hiss and rush that came to her from the choppy surface. She swept the sonar mics in a circle covering every direction out from the Prospect and back again. Having not found anything, she would then begin again. The continual effort at maintaining her attention on the search butted against the complete lack of any signal to focus on or track. She was beginning to think the best move might be to go check that they had enough food and water supplies to survive weeks of drifting on open ocean.

Except then, way off their rear port side, a soft throbbing came into her headset. She closed her eyes. It was faint and threaded, like the last heartbeats of a leviathan. She opened her eyes and glanced at the radar sweep, but it remained completely clean.

She called Hemi over. â€œListen to this, and tell me what you think it is.â€

Hemi had exceptional ears for sonar. He stood next to her and put the headphones on and his eyes lost focus as he listened. The tips of his thick brown fingers rested on the top of the directional control wheel and eased it back and forth across the contactâ€™s heading.

â€œVery small surface craft, and movingâ€¦ unusual though â€” and not just because it is tiny and in the deep ocean. It seems like it has almost no hull sound. I do not hear any wake running along it.â€

â€œCan you calculate a range?â€

â€œIt is close. Let me see.â€ He looked at the dials of the sonar unit and scribbled some numbers on a scrap paper. â€œTwo nautical miles, thereabouts maybe? I think you should be able to see it with the periscope.â€

Percy nodded and climbed up into the control compartment. She raised the periscope up and spun it around to the bearing of the target. She rolled the scope barrel slowly back and forth along the horizon line, where the dark gray of the water press-fit up against the light gray of the sky. With the Prospect on the surface, and the scope up, she could see something like ten nautical miles on a clear day. This was as good as vision ever got on a submarine.

â€œEven if it were a fucking canoeâ€¦ at two miles away I should be able to see it.â€ There was nothing but unblemished gray fields in her scope. She double-checked the bearing with Hemi, shouting down to the sonar station below.

She was pointed in the right direction, there was simply nothing there.

She had a hunch though. She felt confident about the sonar target. She was sure something was there despite the fact that underwater sound can sometimes play tricks. The lack of any visual on the surface narrowed down the possibilities of what it could be.

â€œHemi,â€ she called down again to the compartment below, â€œI want to motor over closer to it. Keep tracking it on sonar.â€

Captain Percy put Bastian back in the rudder-throttle control seat. She gave him a heading towards the sonar target and they put one of the electric motors in gear. Her eyes locked on the battery gauge, which waved slightly as the motor started turning, drawing the last amperage from the depleted battery banks. The needles on the battery gauges were deep in the red now. There was such a very little gap of air between them and the zero mark. They would only get one shot at this.

âŸ

They crept â€” two nautical miles an hour. After a quarter-hour or so, Hemi called up from sonar, â€œWe got lucky Sylvia. I am tracking something like an intercept course â€” the object is headed towards us at any rate. At our current speed there is no way we would ever have overtaken it if they were heading away from us. It is moving fairly quickly. Butâ€¦â€ There was a gap, and Percy could hear him scratching a pencil on paper. â€œBut, we need to go slightly faster, can you do four knots?â€

Percy sighed. It did not sound like much, but it was twice as much power consumption. â€œYou heard the man Bastian, give her a little fuckinâ€™ gas.â€

There was a burning cigarette between Bastianâ€™s bony fingers as they wrapped around the throttle stick and eased it slightly forward.

A few minutes later Hemi called up, â€œGood. We will be within a quarter mile of the object in a matter of minutes.â€

â€œThey must be able to fucking see us. They havenâ€™t changed direction or speed?â€

â€œNo.Â Maybe nobody is looking, or they just do not care.â€

Captain Percy stayed on the periscope, slowly tracking across the bearing. Still nothing.

â€œSylvia!â€ called up Hemi, â€œthey are gone. No detectable signal on the sonar.â€

â€œStop the boat Bastian.â€ The electric motors were very quiet when running this slow, but she wanted Hemi to have total silence for listening. â€œWhat was the last range Hemi?â€

â€œAbout 500 meters. They are close. I have to assume they are just sitting idle out there. We could ping them?â€

â€œAh, that would scare the fucking shit out of them. They might think we were armed and about to fire. Weâ€™re trying to make friends here. â€¦Iâ€™m going to try ship-to-ship radio. Weâ€™re just close enough they might hear us, and the radio could be a little less threatening.â€

Percy reached over her head and flipped on the ship-to-ship radio. A device that was not actually a radio, it was just acted like one. It used the sonar rig to push sound through the water to talk to other ships nearby. 500 meters was just about the limit of its range. Real radio transmissions were supposed to follow a set of protocols and rules, potentially enforced by agents of Authorities in their respective territories. Ship-to-ship had no rules other than an informal argot that had developed partially to obfuscate meaning for any other ship that might be listening, and partially just evolved from nautical cultural habit.

Captain Percy took down the mic from the radio and brought it to her lips. She pushed the transmit button, and the needles on the radio unitâ€™s gauges jumped to show how much power she was transmitting with. She whistled a series of five randomish tones into the mic, and let go of the transmit button. The power needles died back to zero, and there was silence for a minute or two.

Then she repeated the transmission of the tones. Another minute passed.

Then a crackly male voice came over the radio, â€œI see you over there, you hulking ugly gray fuckinâ€™ submarine. And I guess you know Iâ€™m here. Why are ya sittinâ€™ on the surface, and what do ya want with me?â€

Percy hesitated, and then transmitted back, â€œwell, first let me state flat out that weâ€™re nothing but a cargo sub â€” and let me emphasize: un-fucking-armed. Second, weâ€™ve been severely damaged, and swam through an icy hell to get back to the surface. Weâ€™re out of fuel and extremely low on power. Long and short is that weâ€™re in some desperate need of help, and you are the only contact weâ€™ve seen in these fucking desolate waters.â€

Another moment passed. â€œYeah. Well. These waters are empty because the Authorities running this territory right now are a bunch of tight-sphinctered class-A holes who seem more interested in shooting down transports than letting any commerce commence. Itâ€™s a fucking bad place to be not moving and on the surface.â€

â€œNot moving is hardly typical for us. What are you sitting on there? We donâ€™t see any ship in the scope. Any assistance you can offer would be much appreciated.â€

â€œEhh, Iâ€™m not one who is much for offering assistance, so for the next few minutes here I think Iâ€™m not going to show ya what Iâ€™m riding. But if yer telling the truth, I donâ€™t envy your dire-ass situation.â€

â€œI absolutely understand your unwillingness to not tip your hand. Anything I can do to reassure you we arenâ€™t anything other than what we say we are?â€

â€œThe territorial Authority motherfuckers around here generally just shoot first, check papers later. Theyâ€™re not much for mind games. So the fact that you havenâ€™t already shot at me says a lot.â€

There was a long pause of radio silence. Percy held the mic off-angle in her hand while listening. She began to worry that she had lost their only chance for help.

The ship-to-ship crackled back to life. â€œAlright. I think I can risk pulling alongside ya, and poppinâ€™ the hatch. Donâ€™t send nobody onto my boat without my say-so, or Iâ€™ll dive straight out from under ya. Fuckingâ€™ got it?â€

â€œWeâ€™ll look for you â€” for something â€” off the port side. Out.â€

âŸ

â€œHemi,â€ Percy called down to sonar, â€œweâ€™ve got ourselves something, though Iâ€™m hardly sure what. You and Bastian come up on deck with me.â€

Bastian unfolded his long skinny legs from a cramped-looking position where his feet were propped up on the control panel. He climbed up through the hatch and via the ladder to the bridge of the sail with Percy and Hemi following. The wind was blowing a little harder and the chop had kicked up. Bastian cupped his hands and lit another cigarette. Percy and Hemi shaded their eyes, scanning the water. It was a few minutes before they saw a small gray oblong object cutting through the choppy little waves. It was a tiny submarine sail, no more than a meter long and high, with a couple of thin wispy antennas trailing from the top in the wind. Unusual for a submarine, it had a small viewport in the front of the sail through which the pilot could look. At the rear of the sail a stream of diesel smoke floated up and away behind it. The deck of the tiny sub was totally awash, running just under the surface of the water.

As it got closer they could see the big splotchy patches of rust all along the hull of the mini-sub, and a slight oil slick of a trail that it left behind in its minimal wake. Bastian, Hemi, and Percy climbed over the fairing of the Prospectâ€™s sail and down to the deck. Standing here, Percy was somewhat sickened to see the angle of the deck and the bow of her boat sitting much lower than usual, still weighed down by the tons of excess ballast water.

A moment passed before a hatch opened at the top of the sail of the mini-sub, and the head of a man with yellow spiked hair emerged. His arms were still inside the sail working controls and he was standing propped on something inside so he could get his head and shoulders up high enough above the fairing to see as he guided it alongside the Prospect.

Bastian opened the hatch to a wet-storage locker on the deck and pulled out some large white rubber bumpers that were flat and deflated after being subjected to the underwater pressure. He connected each to a short hose that led to a fixture for the low-pressure compressed air system inside the wet-storage locker, and let a little puff of air into the bumpers until they had been restored to more or less their normal shape. Each bumper had a long line that he tied off to recessed deck cleats and lowered down between the two subs.

â€œToss a line!â€ the main in the mini-sub yelled as he let the engine run on idle and stepped over the fairing. He was wearing tall rubber boots as he ran up the washed deck of the small sub. The boots were pulled over leather pants that were originally probably black, but now were cracked and gray at the seams and joints. From the left side of his broken leather belt hung a couple of sizes of adjustable wrenches, the finish on the them beat away, matte and rusting in places, from years of banging against each other like chimes. He wore a faded black denim vest from which the sleeves had been inexpertly removed leaving stray threads of denim trailing behind him in the breeze and exposing a pair of sinewy arms.

Bastian, still with a cigarette between his lips, threw across a line. The sub pilot made it fast to a cleat welded onto the hull of the mini-sub, and then repeated the move at the stern. He nimbly leaped across to the hand-holds on the side of the Prospect and climbed up the curving side to the deck.

He looked around with a nervous twitch, and then motioned to Bastian for a cigarette, who cupped his hand and lit one off his own before handing it to him.

The man took the cigarette between hid fingers and brought it to his lips to suck long and hard at it. â€œAh fuck thanks. I ran out a couple of days ago. I go by Shakes.â€ He held up his hand level in front of them and they could see it tremble slightly in the air. â€œYa can see why.â€ Shakes looked at Hemi standing just ahead of Percy with his black beard wafting in the breeze. â€œYou the captain?â€

Hemi nodded toward Percy. She stuck a grimy hand out. â€œCaptain Percy. Hemi here is my submersible giant and Deck Boss. The skinny one is Bastian.â€

â€œThat the whole complement?â€

â€œFew more below.â€ Percy was still staring at the mini-sub, â€œthatâ€™s a hell of a fucked-up craft ya got there.â€

â€œLike it? I built it my fuckinâ€™ self. Welded it together on the top of a mountain coffee farm from rotting scraps of metal. They had a bunch of land higher up where the coffee donâ€™t grow, and it seemed like a good place to build a boat. It was. Cept it wasnâ€™t a good place to launch a boat from. Getting it down to the water was way more difficult than the buildinâ€™ of it.â€

â€œI could imagine,â€ said Hemi.

â€œIâ€™ve heard of this kind of thing,â€ said Percy, â€œthe boat runs fast and just below the surface. Basically invisible to any kind of radar, and too quiet for most sonar. Good forâ€¦ small shipments?â€

â€œAye, â€˜Specialty shipmentsâ€™ â€” when stuff has to be got somewhere fast with no fucking questions asked. Just not too much stuff. I also built in a few special modifications â€” this here boat is the fastest and most versatile in its class!â€

Captain Percy looked at the rusting bulbous hulk alongside her boat and doubted there was any class of vessel that would accept it.

Shakes continued, â€œmost of these homemade jobs just run at the surface; I added some batteries and some trim tanks, and this here boat â€” the Gnat is the name â€” can dive. Run a bit under water, just enough to get away from any curious onlookers.â€

â€œHow deep?â€ asked Hemi.

â€œMaybe 30 meters on a good day, if you really pushed it. You donâ€™t have to go very deep to hide something so small.â€

â€œHow fast?â€ Hemi could not deny his curiosity now.

Shakes grinned. â€œFaster than this fuckinâ€™ barge.â€ He said kicking the toe of his rubber boot against the hull of the Prospect.

Percy frowned. â€œWelp, thatâ€™s an impressive submersible hobby you got there. But has anyone here got an idea how how weâ€™re going to get my boat moving? You ainâ€™t carrying a load of diesel fuel are you Mr.Â Shakes?â€

â€œCaptain Shakes, if you fuckinâ€™ please. And I certainly ainâ€™t got fuel to spare. And I canâ€™t say what I am carrying, ceptinâ€™ that I canâ€™t see how any of it could help you. Still, if I can do anything to assist, Iâ€™m game â€” at least if thereâ€™s a little something in it for me. Iâ€™m pretty convinced yâ€™all ainâ€™t some Authority ruse, and we smugglers gotta stick together, I fucking say.â€

â€œWeâ€™re not smugglers,â€ said Percy, her eye firmly locked on Shakes. â€œWeâ€™re independent logistics operators.â€

â€œAinâ€™t we fucking all!â€ said Shakes. â€œHonestly, I ainâ€™t got much in the way of ideas for ya. I was thinking maybe you were the smart ones. From what I can see yâ€™all are fuckinâ€™ fucked. Best I can say is I could run into my destination port and send some friendly bigger ship back out for you. But thatâ€™ll probably take a couple days at least.â€

â€œIn a couple of days weâ€™ll either be sunk or in some Authority holding cell. Thereâ€™s gotta be a better option. Hemi?â€ Percy turned to him.

â€œWell, nothing immediately comes to mind. But that is with limited information. If a new option has arisen, it will be aboard the Gnat. To assess the situation, I would need to get in there and take a look at what resources you have got aboard. Iâ€™m not sure how willing you are to let me do that.â€

Shakes did not say anything, but pulled on his cigarette and watched the exhaled smoke quickly blown out over the water by the breeze.

â€œLook, we arenâ€™t the type to ask for help,â€ Percy said, â€œand I hate imposing on other folksâ€™ business, just as I donâ€™t want â€™em imposing on mine, but you can see weâ€™re more than a little desperate here. If you can see your way to allowing Hemi â€” and just Hemi â€” aboard to take some specs of your boat â€” see if youâ€™re carrying anything he can use â€” weâ€™ll make it up to you later. â€¦At the current moment about all we can offer you is hot food.â€

Shakes eyes brightened at that. â€œHrm. Well Iâ€™ve been eatinâ€™ nothing but cold chow straight from the can for a week now. A hot meal is maybe a stronger offer than you realize at the moment. Alright. This big guy, and him alone. And he donâ€™t look at nothing I donâ€™t want him to look at. And he donâ€™t get answers to questions I donâ€™t want to answer. No fucking pushinâ€™, right?â€

â€œNo pushing,â€ said Hemi.

â€œRight. Hang back a minute, let me go look around in there first, make sure all my pornography is put away. When I give you the signal, come across.â€

Percy grinned as Shakes lowered himself down the side and leapt nimbly over the dangerous gap between the two boats where the chop occasionally ground the two walls of rusting steel against each other, crushing the breath out of the cracked old bumpers. He disappeared through the sail hatch of the Gnat.

â€œInteresting character,â€ said Hemi.

â€œSolo operatorsâ€¦ nobody who is comfortable spending days or weeks at sea alone â€” eating fucking cold canned food no less â€” ever totally has their head screwed on right. Anyway, it doesnâ€™t matter how pleasant a person he is. The question is, do you think thereâ€™s anything you can do with that boat thatâ€™s going to help us?â€

â€œI am not entirely hopeful. It is not much of a craft, and is not likely to have much in the way of resources aboard. Frankly, I am surprised he is not lost and dead in the water himself.â€

â€œFind us something Hemi. But donâ€™t do anything to set that tweaked motherfucker off while youâ€™re over there.â€

â€œI shall be like a lamb among the lions.â€

From the sail of the Gnat Shakesâ€™ head and arm popped up and gestured. â€œCome on over man-mountain. Mind the fuckinâ€™ gap!â€

Hemiâ€™s size made for a thrilling sight as he hopped the crunching span between the two boats, but he proved just as nimble as Shakes had been. Hemi was wearing heavy but conventional leather boots, and the water washing the deck of the Gnat soaked the lower part of his legs. The tweed pants of his suit turned a dark and sagging color. He stepped over the open hatch into the sail, and from where Percy was watching, it seemed for a moment like there was no way his bulk would get down that tiny hole. But Hemi lithely disappeared into the boat.

Percy gave Bastian a pull on the sleeve, and he tossed a smoked-out butt into the ocean before they climbed up the sail and back inside the Prospect.

âŸ

â€œSo what do you think? Ainâ€™t it the finest fuckinâ€™ boat ya ever had the pleasure of dropping inside of?â€ Shakes seemed genuinely proud.

â€œItâ€™s certainly a masterpiece of the genre,â€ replied Hemi, even more evenly than usual.

Hemi had spent nearly his entire life among and inside filthy machines, but he had never seen anything where the grime lay down quite as thickly as this. There was literal garbage all over the deck: empty cans, candy wrappers, and various greasy machine parts all rolled back back and forth with the swell. A big open tin that had once contained herring served as an ashtray but seemed like it had not been used for ash but merely as a target to toss used butts at â€” most of which had missed and lay scattered about.

There were stacks of pornography â€” Shakes had not bothered to hide any of it. Or at least Hemi hoped that was true, because the stacks on display were of a class so deviant that Hemi could not imagine what Shakes would have deigned to feel needed hiding.

In one space, recessed between the supports of the pressure hull, were columns of food cans still unopened. The labels had been peeled off and the contents written on them in grease pencil. Most appeared to be of some variety of highly-salted pasta-and-sauce. In another recess was a bin with what must have been a hundred different types of puzzle games that all had the basic premise of requiring squares of color to be sorted alike. Every single last puzzle was solved.

The controls to the sub were aligned with and partially inside of the sail. Hemi noted that the controls were airplane-style: with a single yoke that controlled both the angle and direction of the boat â€” a pretty sophisticated system for any submarine, but particularly a hand-built machine.

The sail was the only place with enough headroom to stand upright. Or, at least Shakes could stand upright there, Hemi still had to crouch a bit. Through an open hatch leading forward, Hemi could see small wooden crates crammed into the bow section. More crates were arranged behind the controls located in the middle of the boat. Shakes had thrown what were clearly his sleeping blankets over the crates. There was a thin heavily-stained mattress to one side, which Shakes was raising to lean against the pressure hull so there was enough room to pass the crates.

â€œYâ€™all woke me from a nap with the fuckinâ€™ ship-to-ship call. Thatâ€™s why I didnâ€™t see ya earlier. I suppose you want to see the engines and batteries and what-fuckin-not? Theyâ€™re toward the back.â€ Shakes reached into his denim vest and withdrew a leather pouch. He pinched some dried leaves from it and stuffed them into his cheek and masticated them slowly.

â€œYes, the engines first if you please.â€ Hemi squeezed past the crates and pulled a small notebook and pencil from an inside pocket of his tweed jacket. The engine was massive and took up the entire rear third of the boat. Now Hemi was genuinely impressed, â€œthatâ€™s a lot of engine for such a small vessel.â€

â€œTook the thing out of a fuckinâ€™ tractor that had been broken down and rustinâ€™ in a coffee field for years. Had to build a gantry and borrow another tractor to haul it up the mountain to where I was building the Gnat and get it installed. Direct-drive to the prop, so itâ€™s a genuine ship engine, not just a glorified generator to power an electric motor.â€

The configuration was obvious to Hemi. The greasy steel drive shaft came straight from the back end of the diesel running along the center-line of the boat and passed out through the stern, like an egg on its side, pierced by a needle.

â€œBut you said it has batteries too, the boat can swim underwater?â€

â€œSure, the direct-shaft drive means Iâ€™ve gotta have a transmission of course. I worked with a mechanical genius who lived on the coffee farm to build this fancy-ass transmission that lets me switch over to that electric motor to drive. Itâ€™s a fuckinâ€™ hassle though, I try to avoid it, â€˜cept in emergencies. I have to leave the controls and come back here to the engines, switch out the diesel and manually engage the electric motor with these levers. And the electric motor is small â€” itâ€™s slow; though fuckinâ€™ silent as a sunken graveyard.â€

â€œIt is the finest piece of mountain-top engineering Iâ€™ve ever seen on the sea,â€ Hemi said honestly. â€œIs that an escape trunk back there?â€

â€œYessir. Never know what you might need to be flushinâ€™ out of the fuckinâ€™ boat, including meself.â€

â€œAnd where are the batteries?â€

â€œEh, batteries, fuel, ballast tanks are all below these deck panels. You have to pull them up to get at them. Since I rarely use the electric motor, the batteries almost always have a full charge on them â€” as they do right now â€” if that helps somehow. Obviously not enough juice to power your giant fuckinâ€™ washtub over there.â€

â€œNo, not nearly. How much fuel do you have?â€

â€œWellsir, this is how we check thatâ€¦â€ Shakes slipped his finger through a metal ring atop a pipe that ran upward from the deck along the curve of the wall. He pulled a long wavering piece of thin steel from the pipe and wiped it on a foul rag that hung on a hook on the wall. He replaced the dipstick and then quickly pulled it back out again and held it up for Hemi to see the graduation along the dipstick.

Hemi winced as he caught an acrid whiff of petrochemicals off the dipstick. â€œYou buy decent quality fuel oil Captain Shakes?â€

â€œAh well fuck, you know: I buy whatever I can get at the trading posts. Iâ€™m sure theyâ€™re sometimes selling me chunky bunker with the used oil from the cafeteria deep fryer dumped on top. But ainâ€™t that what the fuckinâ€™ fuel filter is for?â€ Shakes kicked at a rust-flaked cylinder mounted on a pipe running back towards the engine. â€œI consider it good quality fuel if I donâ€™t hafta siphon water out of the bottom of the tank after a top-up.â€

â€œIndeed. And how long will that amount of fuel oil you have there last you?â€ Hemi asked, pointing the eraser side of his pencil at the dripping dipstick Shakes was still holding between them.

â€œMaybe twelve hours worth left. Enough to get me where Iâ€™m fuckinâ€™ going.â€

â€œWhere are you going?â€

â€œI think Iâ€™m gonna keep that bit aâ€™ information to myself for the moment.â€ Shakes set the dipstick back in its pipe.

Hemi made a sound in his throat while he scribbled some calculations. He pointed to a gauge in front of the control yoke, â€œis that the battery charge?â€

â€œSuch as it is. Thatâ€™s salvaged from tractor parts too. It shows me roughly how much charge is left on the battery, but mostly itâ€™s just got a fuckinâ€™ little red light that comes on when the batteries are about to kick off. If ya want any fuckinâ€™ precision, you gotta get down under those deck panels with the meter and take readings off each of the battery banks.â€ Shakes kicked a small steel door that opened to a recessed cabinet in the wall. He pulled from the space a short pry bar and a small metal box with a dial gauge and a pair of electrical leads dangling from it. â€œCheck this shit out.â€ He levered the teeth of the prybar under the steel deck panel. Hemi stood on the other side and they lifted the panel together and propped it up.

Below were rows and rows of what Hemi was almost certain were lead-acid truck or tractor batteries. A ratâ€™s nest of greasy black cables ran back and forth between them.

Hemi scratched his beard. â€œWell! Let me see that meter.â€ He lowered himself to his knees and reached out over the battery banks with the leads from the meter. He began touching the probes to various terminals on the batteries and writing down the results he read off the meter in his little notebook. â€œThis is going to take a while.â€

â€œAlways fuckinâ€™ does.â€ Shakes took a comb from his pocket and dipped it in a bucket half-filled with oil that dripped from the diesel engine. He ran the comb through his hair, then teased it back up to a spiky randomness with the tips of his fingers. He wiped his fingers on his shirt. â€œSoâ€¦ where were you guys headed, before the whole fuckinâ€™ dead-ship thing?â€

Hemi didnâ€™t look up from his work. â€œCaptain Percy has been playing that particular piece of information close to her chest since we left the last port. I believe she has a line on our next job, but she has not yet shared details with me,â€ Hemi said somewhat tentatively. He continued silently checking the status of the batteries while Shakes pulled a pack of cigarettes from his vest and lit one to chase down the flavor of the leaves he had been chomping on.

After Shakes had filled up the small space with a haze of tobacco smoke, Hemi sat up straight and stashed his notebook and pencil back in his pocket. â€œI think I have enough information for the time being. That food Gregory was working on is probably ready. Shall we go see if we can find something hot to eat?â€

â€œShit ya. My gut is a gaping hole. Help me get this panel back in place.â€ Shakes tossed the remaining bit of burning cigarette in the direction of the ashtray, and Hemi helped him replace the panel.

âŸ

Shakes and Hemi came into the galley of the Prospect with Captain Percy and Bastian already crammed into the tight seating around the table. Gregory was working a giant cast iron pan at the stove so heavy with frying rice that the wiry muscles of the arm controlling the pan bulged with the effort of shaking it.

Gregory looked up when Hemi and Shakes came in. Hemi introduced Shakes.

â€œFuck yeah,â€ said Shakes eyeing the pile of frying rice, â€œI ainâ€™t eaten nothing but cold canned pasta for more than a week.â€

â€œNone of your canned garbage food here, Captain Shakes,â€ said Gregory, grinding the pan back and forth across the range in a way that set small sparks flying. â€œGotta keep it moving or itâ€™ll burn to the bottom. This is real submarinerâ€™s food. Everything good that canâ€™t go bad: rice, eggs, cabbageâ€¦â€

â€œAre you putting that foul slimy-gray pickled cabbage in the rice again Gregory?â€ asked Bastian, â€œyouâ€™ll be killing submariners if submarinerâ€™s food is that fucking real.â€

Gregory huffed. â€œMy olâ€™ pap worked a submarine galley in the wars. He used to say â€˜if you can heat it, you can eat it.â€™ And this shitâ€™s gonna be plenty fucking hot.â€ Gregory dumped in an entire container of the questionable pickled cabbage, and stirred it around as the sound of frying drowned out any conversation.

He declared the rice done a few minutes later. â€œCaptain Shakes, for helping us out, youâ€™re up first.â€ Gregory cracked an egg onto a smoking smaller frying pan next to the giant one full of rice. As it sizzled on the creosote surface, Gregory dumped huge piles of rice into a big bowl and handed it to Shakes. The rice was browned by the black salty sauces Gregory had poured into it, and burned to a crusty-black crunchiness in places. Steaming bits of cabbage slithered throughout, flecked with red and black pepper. Shakes was about to dig a fork in when Gregory slipped the fried egg on top with a spatula. Its white was stained an oily, slightly-gray color, and the glowing orange yolk was held in place by a wiggling skin on the edge of being burst from the pressure of the hot liquid inside.

Shakes grinned before plunging the tines of his fork into the yolk and letting it run into his rice. He then started working his way into his bowl with an uninterrupted shoveling motion of his fork from the bowl to his mouth.

Gregory served up the rest of the crew the same way. Captain Percy asked him to run up to the control room and get on the PA and tell Owen to come up for some grub.

Hemi sat at the end of the table with his little notebook propped open in front of him, eating his rice with one hand while scribbling down calculations with the other.

Their hunger got the better of any conversation for a few minutes as the mounds of rice, egg, and cabbage steadily vanished. Gregory served himself and sat down, and got back up a few minutes later to fry another egg for Owen when he arrived. A few minutes after that, he had to get up to make Shakes another egg. All told, every one of them had at least two servings and Owen and Shakes each ate three servings apiece. Gregory never got to sit for more than a minute. And when no more eggs were being demanded, he got up again to put coffee on.

Between forkfuls of rice, Captain Percy tried to get an assessment of the situation on her boat. â€œOwen, have you been down in the cargo hold?â€ Owen nodded, his crop fully loaded. â€œHowâ€™s the patch looking?â€

Owen swallowed, and then swallowed again. â€œIâ€™m hardly an expert on welding or repairs, but Iâ€™d say it looks pretty bad. The patches are an ugly mess, and Iâ€™m pretty sure the water level is rising again, though more slowly.â€

â€œCan you work on it? Can you clean up those welds, get the leaking stopped?â€ Percy asked.

â€œI can try. But you know itâ€™s delicate work that Iâ€™m just starting to figure out. Thereâ€™s a chance I could just make it worse â€” burn a hole right through the hull. If youâ€™re asking me, I think you need Chips on it.â€

â€œI didnâ€™t ask your opinion you little shit. I asked if you can fix it,â€ said Percy, aiming her fork at him.

â€œYeah, Captain Percy. No fuckinâ€™ sweat.â€ Owen poked at his food a little less hungrily.

â€œFinish your food and get your skinny ass back down there.â€

â€œSylvia,â€ Hemi said, not looking up from his food. â€œI really think you need to do what you can to get Chips back to working on those repairs.â€

She smacked her fist on the table and looked up, breathing through her nostrils. â€œFuck.â€

âŸ

Owen took his coffee to go, and headed towards the cargo hold to try and reinforce Chipsâ€™ patches. When there was finally a cup of coffee in front of everyone remaining in the galley, and the empty bowls pushed into the middle of the table, Percy brought them to order. â€œNext agenda item: assuming we donâ€™t fucking sink, how do we get my lady moving again?â€ She looked at Hemi.

Hemi put his pencil down. â€œPerhaps in your time on the sea some of you have become familiar with the Angler fish? In some species the female is enormous compared to the male, maybe a hundred times bigger. The females are complex, highly evolved organisms, with sophisticated traps for catching and devouring other fish. The males are nothing but tiny sperm repositories. They swim around until they find a female, attach themselves to the femaleâ€™s underside, and then fuse with her body, essentially becoming nothing more than a sperm organ for her.â€

â€œHemi, letâ€™s try stepping around the long-winded symbolism and get to the fucking point,â€ Percy said.

â€œHere is what I propose,â€ Hemi continued unfazed, â€œthe Prospect has a hatch with a mating collar on the bottom side of the boat. â€œGot it,â€ Percy interrupted, â€œand you think thereâ€™s enough juice left in the Gnat forâ€¦ what? How far could that possibly take us?â€

â€œHold the fuck on a second,â€ Shakes cut in, â€œWhat exactly do I get out of your little biology lesson Hemi? Captain Percy blew out her cheeks. â€œOK look. First: you are not going to be crew, you are our guest Shakes.â€

â€œCaptain Shakes.â€

â€œOur guest, Captain Shakes. Assuming youâ€™re all done gorging yourselves, letâ€™s regroup at the navigation table and Iâ€™ll show you what Iâ€™m thinking.â€

â€œAnything that profitable has got to be illegal,â€ said Shakes as they slid out from the galley table bench seats.

â€œAs you know, what is illegal in one territory is a high-value commodity in another, at least for most cargo,â€ said Hemi.

â€œOh, I wasnâ€™t judging; just, ya know, clarifying. Regional high-value commodities are the Gnatâ€™s bread and butter.â€

They made their way forward and regrouped around the navigation table, most still holding their tin coffee mugs.

â€œSo where are we now?â€ asked Shakes between sips.

Hemi pointed to the obvious small x at the end of a string of grease pencil dashes.

â€œTo pick this job up, we need to reach the destination I had been aiming for before we got side-tracked,â€ said Percy, â€œand that destination is here.â€ She pointed to a small feature on the chart with a grease-stained finger.

Shakes set his coffee mug down on the glass covering the chart and pulled down the retractable magnifier. He leaned over the chart and read the label of the feature Percy had pointed to. â€œIt says, â€˜deserted.â€™ Thatâ€™s where your big fuckinâ€™ score awaits Captain Percy? A deserted island?â€

â€œIt was deserted when this chart was made. And the current residents would probably prefer the charts remain labeled that way. But over the last ten years or so, a small depot was built there. Lookâ€¦â€ She took the grease pencil and drew a lightweight but long line across hundreds of miles of ocean. â€œThe Territorial Authority boundary is roughly about here. With total assholes on this side we are currently on, and only sort-of assholes on the other. So you can see how it makes sense to put a depot on that deserted island just across the line to help facilitate trade in, out, and through Asshole-vania over here.â€

â€œThe Authority on this side of the line are a bunch of aggressive motherfuckinâ€™ assholes,â€ agreed Shakes. â€œThey must just hate having that depot there.â€

â€œThatâ€™s why the proprietors would prefer the island to generally be understood to remain â€˜deserted.â€™ And itâ€™s also why the assholes patrolling the water weâ€™re currently in are particularly unfriendly dicks to good folks likes ourselves in the business of shipping. â€œWell, when you put it that way â€” that particularly profitable way, I meanâ€¦â€

Hemi picked up a pair of calipers and measured the distance between the small grease-pencil x and the deserted island. â€œAbout 100 nautical milesâ€¦â€ he muttered mostly to himself. Could.â€

â€œWait a damned second, I put it to you again: what do I get out of this fuckinâ€™ mechanical monstrosity of a plan?â€ Shakes was stabbing his finger against the table, leaving smudgy black prints on the glass.

â€œI can pay you up front for the fuel we take from you today Captain Shakes,â€ said Percy, â€œand at the depot Iâ€™ll pay you your standard hull rate, plus refill your fuel oil. So itâ€™s like youâ€™re getting paid for a full shipping run just for accompanying us to the depot.â€

â€œYou mean if you get into that there â€˜highly profitableâ€™ line though donâ€™t ya? What if you find that fuckinâ€™ line has dried up?â€

â€œIn that case, weâ€™ll have to work something else out that is within our means. You afraid of a little gambling Captain Shakes?â€

â€œWhat about my current load? This little fuckinâ€™ adventure of yours is going to set be back a couple of days at least. What do I tell my current client?â€

â€œWhere is your drop-off?â€

â€œWell, I was headed for the Longland Islands trading center. Refuel there; and then on to my drop-off destination a few days out beyond that.â€

â€œComâ€™on buddy,â€ said Bastian, â€œlook at the fuckinâ€™ chart; itâ€™s nearly the same direction! Shakes considered the chart. There was no arguing with Bastianâ€™s point though.

â€œPlus we will fit a nice mating collar onto the Gnat. You may find that to be of some use in the future,â€ said Hemi, â€œthink of it as a deluxe feature.â€

â€œAnd hot meals till we get to the depot,â€ added Gregory.

Shakes glanced at Gregory with a look that suggested he might be bought cheap if the pay satisfied his stomach. â€œI need one other thing thoughâ€¦ I want you to keep a line open to me on any future job possibilities.â€

â€œWhat.. like fuckinâ€™ partners?â€ Percy bristled.

â€œFuck no. I work alone. But an operator has to have connections in this game. Youâ€™d be a big cheese for me; feeding me future prospects. That way I get long-term payoffs for my investment in your sorry-ass fuckinâ€™ futures right now.â€

â€œAlright. Any job that seems suitable for a specialty cargo hauler like yourself, I will send your way with fuckinâ€™ pleasure.â€

Shakes grinned. Now they were negotiating from a place he understood â€” most profit is future profit. â€œSo, ah, Hemi, what exactly are ya going to do to my beautiful little boat?â€

â€œWell,â€ Hemi said, looking at Percy, â€œfirst, we need to rouse Chips. She is the only one on board who might know how to fit a mating collar that could work.â€

Percy was grinding her teeth. â€œAlright, Fuck. Hemi, go see if you can rehire Chips on a temporary and ad-fucking-hoc basis to do some of this welding we need. I donâ€™t want to see her though. âŸ

Hemi loaded up another bowl of rice from the galley and led Shakes to the crew quarters where they found Chips in her rack with the curtains drawn.

â€œChips,â€ Hemi addressed the curtain, â€œI brought you some food.â€

â€œAh fuck you and your gestures Hemâ€™,â€ came a muffled voice from behind the curtain. â€œGo spoon it into that twat you work for until she fuckinâ€™ chokes on it.â€

â€œChips, you are certainly tough, no one would deny that. â€œSpare me the fuckinâ€™ youâ€™re-both-so-fuckinâ€™-alike speech Hemi. Just fuck off.â€

â€œI am just explaining why she is not going to come apologize, Chips. I am also going to tell you I believe she was entirely wrong, and risked your life by not warning you she was going to blow the tanks. You were right, and she should apologize, but you know her â€” she will not.â€

â€œSo fuckinâ€™ what? You think I give a shit?â€

â€œSo I do not believe you want to die out here just because she is never going to do the right thing and admit she made a mistake. There was a silence. Then a small, filthy hand stuck out from behind the curtain. â€œGive me that food, Iâ€™m fucking starving.â€ Hemi put the warm bowl of rice into the hand, and it withdrew. There was a clinking of the fork for a minute, and then Chips opened the curtain a little so she could look at Hemi and talk to him while she ate. Thatâ€™s when she saw Shakes. â€œWho the fuck is that?â€

â€œIâ€™m fuckinâ€™ Shakes,â€ said Shakes.

â€œCaptain Shakes,â€ said Hemi.

â€œIs that your name or how you reproduce?â€ asked Chips.

â€œLike youâ€™re one to fuckinâ€™ talk. Didnâ€™t they call you â€˜Chipsâ€™?â€

â€œLook,â€ Hemi interrupted, â€œwe found Captain Shakes here on the surface. He has a boat â€” a small sub. I want to weld a mating collar onto the sail of his boat. It has to fit to the Prospectâ€™s belly mating collar. I want to attach his boat to the underside, and run with it that way. This is another project we cannot do without you. Think you could rig something like that?â€

â€œWell fuck. I might have some scrap steel that could do that. Depends on what the hatch on his boat looks like, so Iâ€™ll have to fuckinâ€™ eyeball that. Possible it could be done.â€ She thought for a second. â€œBut thatâ€™s a fuckinâ€™ tricky bit of sonar listening to make that mating work, steerinâ€™ the boat up from underneath, like. You think you got the fuckinâ€™ skills to do that Captain Shakes?â€

â€œIâ€™ve squeezed that boat through any number of tight places â€” narrow fuckinâ€™ gaps pushing through Authority anti-sub fencing and the like. Iâ€™m as good a sub pilot as there ever fuckinâ€™ was.â€

â€œHis boat, The Gnat, has a viewport in the sail. He should be able to see enough to execute the mating maneuver without the aid of sonar,â€ said Hemi.

â€œA fuckinâ€™ window on a submarine. Stupidest fuckinâ€™ thing I ever heard. Fuckinâ€™ crazy shit ya want to pull here. Look Hemâ€™, youâ€™re right about me not wanting to die out here. Way I figure it is to best push that priority forward, I gotta spend my time workinâ€™ on my fucking patch in the cargo hold. I may in fact spend the rest of my short fuckinâ€™ life working on that fuckinâ€™ patch. I ainâ€™t got time to be up there fuckinâ€™ around with welding scrap steel onto what â€” and Iâ€™m just taking a wild fucking guess here â€” is some barely-afloat rusting sea-tractor.â€ She paused. â€œYou might get Owen to do it.â€

â€œThe kid?â€ asked Shakes, â€œfuck that. If thereâ€™s welding to be done, Iâ€™ll weld my own boat.â€

â€œShe is right though,â€ said Hemi, â€œthe patch in the Prospect needs more work. If it fails, it could take both boats down. Before you do go back to your patch though Chips, get Owen and go out with Captain Shakes and take a look at the Gnat. Make sure they have what they need to get this done right. It is not going to help us much if the mating collar leaks and floods the Gnat. Have Owen haul up the spare welding rig.â€

â€œAye Hemâ€™,â€ she said, understanding that what Hemi actually meant was she should instruct Shakes on how to do the job correctly. She swung down from her bunk handing Hemi her empty food bowl. â€œAnd fuck you for workinâ€™ around my bad mood by siccing me on a right mechanical challenge. Come on Captain Shakes, weâ€™ll go find the fuckinâ€™ kid, and have a look at this boat of yours.â€

âŸ

Hemi found Percy sitting at the sonar station with the headset on, listening. When she saw Hemi, she pulled one earpiece off. â€œThat go OK?â€

â€œYes. Shakes says he is going to do the welding on the Gnat, Chips wants to keep working on the Prospectâ€™s patch.â€

â€œIâ€™m glad she came to her fucking senses.â€

â€œHer senses had little to do with it.â€

Percy ignored that. â€œWhatâ€™s next?â€

â€œI wanted to look at the chart and run my numbers again.â€

â€œAlright. We should put someone on radar, I donâ€™t want any Authority craft sneaking up on us.â€

â€œPut Gregory or Bastian on it.â€

â€œYeah. Alright, Iâ€™ll get Bastian in here. Better than fucking nobody.â€

â€œSend Gregory out to help Owen and Shakes. Welding the mating collar onto the Gnat is going to be a something of a tricky operation.â€

â€œRight.â€ Captain Percy climbed to the control room to rouse her crew on the PA.

âŸ

On the forward deck of the Prospect, Owen had opened the watertight doors of the big cargo hatch. This left a wide hole down into the cavernous space of the cargo hold, which was the only way to get the heavy welding rig out of the boat. He had assembled a small tripod gantry over the hole, and from it he had hung a hefty chain hoist. Gregory was down in the cargo hold securing the end of the chain to the welding rig. When he had it ready, Gregory gave Owen the thumbs up.

â€œHey Gregory,â€ Owen called down to him, â€œwhile Iâ€™m hauling the welding rig up, take a look around: we still need the material for the mating collar. And get the gangway into position, Iâ€™ll need it to wheel this fucking thing across to the Gnat. Also get the long power cables for the welding rig, some heavy clamps, and a welding mask.â€ Owen looked across at the deck of the Gnat with the chop washing over it where Chips and Shakes were drawing lines on the top of the sail with a grease pencil. â€œUhâ€¦ better get those fucking rubber waders too.â€ He lit a cigarette and started hauling the welding rig up, hand-over-hand. â€œThis isnâ€™t going to be easy,â€ he said to himself through the cigarette hanging from his lips. Each long pull on the chain only eased the welding rig below up a matter of centimeters as the lifting capabilities of the chain were both augmented and slowed by the wheels it looped through.

When he finally got the welding rig suspended over the deck, he gave it a little kick, and when it swung back he let the chain out and grabbed the rig as it touched the deck and tilted back toward the hole. This was actually a two-person job, a mistake would mean a 10-meter drop into the cargo hold, and probably being maimed or killed.

Owen wheeled the welding rig away from the cargo hatch and aligned its wheels with the deck of the Prospect so it would not tilt off into the ocean. By the time he got back over the open hole to the cargo hold, Gregory had returned underneath with the gangway. Lashed to the railings of the gangway were the various other things Owen had asked for. Owen dropped the end of the chain down to him, and Gregory clipped it to one end of the gangway. â€œHold on, Iâ€™ll come up and help you haul it.â€ He disappeared toward the stern of the boat.

With Gregory helping to pull the chain through, they hauled the gangway vertically up to the mouth of the cargo hatch, out onto the deck, and got it lashed into place connecting the higher deck of the Prospect to the low, wet deck of the Gnat.

Chips waved Owen over. â€œThanks for doing that fuckinâ€™ gangway. Itâ€™ll be a lot easier getting back to the Prospect.â€ She grinned her rarely-seen, wide-mouthed, slightly gapped-tooth grin at Owen. â€œAlright, look here, this is the plan Shakes and I got worked out, and ya should be glad Shakes is doing it. Itâ€™s going to be a fuckinâ€™ nightmare if it works, and like a fuckinâ€™ wet, squirtinâ€™, languish in the head if it donâ€™t.â€ She pointed to the top of the sail. â€œWe fuckinâ€™ lucked out though, Shakes here built the sail fat enough across the beam that we can make the welds fuckinâ€™ flat. Ya just need a piece of steel cylinder of the right diameter, cut it even, then weld it around the hatch opening. And then weld those spare male docking clamps we got onto the sides of the cylinder.â€

â€œHow am I going to get a cylinder the right diameter?â€

â€œWorst fuckinâ€™ case you have to weld it together out of over-lapping curved pieces. But I think I might have a hunk of steel tube in the scrap pile left over from repairs to the mating collar on the Prospect a while back. In that case we might â€” if youâ€™re a fuckinâ€™ lucky sonof-uh-ho-ar â€” have something exactly the right fucking diameter already.â€

Owen nodded. â€œAnd howâ€™re the docking clamps going to be activated? Theyâ€™re electro-magnetic, right?â€

â€œYeah,â€ said Shakes, â€œweâ€™ll need to drill some through-hull fittings. That sucks, but it shouldnâ€™t be too hard to make them water-tight to 30 meters, which is what I usually call the depth limit of the Gnat. And if they do happen to leakâ€¦ well, theyâ€™ll be pretty small leaks. A boat that donâ€™t leak isnâ€™t a boat, itâ€™s like, a fuckinâ€™ airplane, or something.â€

â€œSince weâ€™re going to be dragging the Gnat along by the mating collar,â€ Owen said, â€œSeems like we should also weld some supports on the outside of the collar, down the sail, and directly to the structural elements of the hull. Itâ€™ll be ugly as fuck, but less likely to leave the Gnat ripped away from the collar.â€

â€œUgly-as-fuck is my other name,â€ said Shakes.

â€œListen to the kid, Capt Shakes. Heâ€™s gettinâ€™ a fuckinâ€™ touch for this stuff,â€ said Chips.

â€œHey, offer all the advice you want, but Iâ€™m the one who puts the fuckinâ€™ torch to my boat, got it?â€

â€œGood by me. Iâ€™ll leave ya stupid fuckers too it. I got my own welding to do.â€ Chips gave them a casual salute and made her way along the gangway to the Prospect.

â€œIâ€™ll get Gregory digging through that scrap steel, see if he can find that tube she was talkinâ€™ about,â€ Owen said.

âŸ

This was going to be an extremely tough job. Not as tough as welding the pressure hull back together under water like Chips was currently doing, Owen reminded himself, but nobody would do this job on the Gnat if they did not have to. Owen had wheeled the welding rig across the gangway, and that had only been modestly harrowing. Connecting it to the Gnatâ€™s questionable electrical system and lashing it to the sloshing hull had been somewhat more so. Owen set Shakes up with everything he needed, handing him tools one-by-one like a nurse supporting a surgeon opening a consumptive rib cage.

The ocean chop was not horrendous, but it was enough that the Gnat rolled back and forth under them. Owen had locked huge iron clamps in place that held the work material to the sail. The water washing over the deck would sometimes smack up against the sail and shoot up right where Shakes would be welding.

Shakes stood astride his boat lolling in the surface of the sea in the same way one might stand on a mountain top. He took a pinch of dried leaves from the pouch in his jacket pocket and stuck them between his teeth. He lit a cigarette, and put it to his lips. He leveled the mask on his head, and slipped the heavy welding gloves onto his hands. He picked up the torch, and standing straight up, opened his arms wide and closed his eyes. He took long slow breaths through gapped lips aside his cigarette, his breathing rattling a little with the spittle coming up to enzymatically dismantle the leaves in his cheek. He cleared his mind and focused on his breathing. He felt the swell and rhythm of the ocean, the time of it marked out by the clink of the adjustable wrenches hanging from his belt. He called the gods of steady hands and perfect welds to him.

He opened his eyes, spit the remaining half of cigarette off into the ocean, leaned over, and flipped the welding mask down.

And with a flash of blue arc, proceeded to lay down the foulest, globbing booger-weld Owen had ever seen. Smoking masses of material built up on top of smoking masses, curled over, and gooped around in carbon-coated black curves. Shakes gripped the welding stick fiercely, the muscles of his forearms tensed up. The tip wavered back and forth across the line the weld was supposed to follow so that it looked like he might be trying to sign the work rather than repair it.

Shakes welded, went back over his work, and welded more. It grew uglier and uglier, globs upon globs of congealed molten metal. The wash of the sea continually soaked the two men in cold water. Every few minutes Shakes had to stop welding so Owen could move the clamps. Since the seam needed to be watertight, Owen wanted to keep it press-fit in place with the clamps at all times. Owen knew that that starting and stopping like that was bad for a welder who wanted to make a clean, strong weld. But since Shakeâ€™s welds were about the worst heâ€™d ever seen, that seemed like the least of his problems. The hot welds steamed when the water ran over them, which Owen was pretty sure would not contribute the strength of the weld.

â€œYouâ€¦ built this boat?â€ Owen asked Shakes, when he raised his head up for a break.

â€œAye fuckinâ€™ ya. On a mountain top.â€

â€œAndâ€¦ it doesnâ€™t leakâ€¦ too much?â€

â€œAh well, ye know thereâ€™s always gonna be â€˜nother leak. I just patch em and keep fuckinâ€™ movinâ€™.â€

â€œLot of patches?â€

â€œSometimes it seems like itâ€™s more patch than original boat. But then, since it was built from scraps, it has always been a fuckinâ€™ quilty kinda thing.â€

By the time they finished welding the support struts down the side of the hull, the new mating collar looked like a bipedal birthday cake, frosted by a toddler using a cancerous mixture of coke and pitch.

â€œYou think thatâ€™ll hold?â€ Owen asked looking at the mess doubtfully.

â€œAw hells ya. Look at how much material we welded into that thing! See, an engineer can build a thing to an exact fuckinâ€™ spec and â€” if theyâ€™re a real right good fuckinâ€™ engineer â€” that thing will perform the way they expect it to, in all the situations they expect it to. The thing is, that donâ€™t mean it will perform in situations the engineer donâ€™t expect. Thatâ€™s why I always overbuild things, far beyond any spec â€” so Iâ€™ll be ready for what I donâ€™t expect.â€

Owen orienteered his way up and down following the thread of that logic, and eventually decided it made absolute sense. â€œWell, nothing like holding a welding project underwater and dragging it along at a few knots to test the quality of your work.â€

â€œAye thatâ€™s what weâ€™ll be fuckinâ€™ doing fer sure when once we got the Gnat set up dragging under your boat over there. Why donâ€™t you go tell that big Hemi guy weâ€™re ready here.â€

âŸ

Getting all the gear from the welding operation stowed back in the cargo hold took longer than expected. The chop was building a bit, and that made doing anything aboard the Gnat more difficult. Once Hemi saw all the odds and ends stowed below and checked the main cargo hatch seal, he went to the forward end of the cargo hold to see how Chips was coming along on her work. She was welding yet more scraps of metal patches over the still-leaking wound in the pressure hull. Thankfully the water level was at least down enough that Chips was wading instead of swimming.

Captain Percy came walking down the cargo hold and met up with Hemi standing at the waterâ€™s edge in the forward end. Chips looked up when she arrived and glared at her, but went immediately back to her welding.

â€œWe are ready to try this connecting up the Gnat move,â€ Hemi said to Percy when she stood next to him.

â€œGood,â€ said Percy through an exhale of her cigarillo smoke. Her eyes were bloodshot and her entire face drooping and wane from lack of sleep. She had another cup of coffee in her other hand. â€œNeed anything else from me when you try the mating?â€
