There, Hemi and Percy made slight adjustments to the trim of the boat, before Hemi returned to the cargo hold to move a few more crates around. It took another hour and three more trips up to the control room before Hemi was happy with the way the cargo sat and the boat was trimmed.

â€œFuckinâ€™ eh Hemi,â€ said Gregory when Hemi was finally settled back into the control room, â€œseemed like the boat was trim enough when we left the fuckinâ€™ depot. Didnâ€™t slow us down none.â€

â€œA submarine is like the hairs on the back of your neck, Gregory. It always needs a trim.â€

âŸ

Hemi knew Captain Percy would keep the same course, depth, and speed until well after dark, and that was still a few hours off yet, so there was little for him to do for the moment. He took the opportunity to start training Cassandra on sonar.

In the sonar compartment, he sent Bastian off for coffee and a smoke and sat down next to Cassandra. â€œYou have been listening for the last few hours while Bastian worked the sonar, correct?â€ Hemi asked her.

Cassandra nodded.

â€œAny of it make any sense?â€

â€œDo you want me to lie?â€

â€œThere is nothing to be concerned about. It is not as complex as it might seem. Except for the parts that are, but we will get to those as we come to them. Put your headset over both earsâ€¦ You need both ears to get a full sense of what any sound you hear on sonar is doing.â€

Cassandra adjusted the headset so it sat evenly with the headphones covering both her ears.

â€œOK,â€ said Hemi as he began adjusting and tuning the sonar unit, â€œthis is the â€˜passiveâ€™ sonar rig. You can think of it as being nothing more than microphones for listening underwater. Thereâ€™s â€˜activeâ€™ sonar too â€” thatâ€™s a lot more complicated: active sonar sends a ping out and we listen for its echo. We do not use that often so do not worry about it for now. Passive is simpler, you are just listening, passively. Get it?â€

Cassandra nodded.

â€œThe main thing you need to know for operating the sonar is that you can aim the underwater microphones in a specific direction using this thing that looks like a steering wheel.â€ Hemi turned the stainless steel wheel a half turn. â€œSee that dial there? That shows you which way the microphones are pointed. It goes around 360 degrees. At some point someone will ask you to listen in a specific direction. They will give you the degrees and you just turn the wheel until the needle on that dial shows you are aiming the mics in the direction they are asking about. Make sense?â€

â€œThat seems simple enough,â€ said Cassandra.

â€œThat part is. It will get a lot more complex when we start using the filters and transducers to tune in on a contact later. The thing is, the ocean is never absolutely silent. Letâ€™s start by just listening to what we hear on the sonar where there are no specific contacts we are trying to focus in on.â€ Hemi and Cassandra both remained quiet for a minute with the background sound of the ocean washing through their headphones. â€œOK Cassandra. What do you hear?â€

â€œI donâ€™t knowâ€¦â€ She waved one small hand around in the air absently. â€œA hissing sound â€” white noise?â€

â€œAlmost anything could be white noise. Describe it with more detail than that.â€

â€œThereâ€™sâ€¦ a low rumble, a bit of a swishing soundâ€¦â€

â€œGood. We are running on the electric motors, underwater, at a modest speed. That is what it sounds like when the boat is moving while submerged. Later, when we are near the surface with the diesel engines running, it will be a lot louder and you will not be able to hear much in the water beyond the engines. But while we are on the electric motors, we can hear more on sonar.

â€œSonar requires imagination,â€ Hemi continued, â€œyou have to put your mind out there in the water. When you hear a sound, you have to match it to an image in your head that shows how the sound could be made. The more detail you can imagine in the image to fit it to the sound, the more accurate your assessment of the contact will be. That is what makes a top sonar person.â€

Hemi pointed to the largest of a set of gauges further up the sonar unit in front of them.

â€œNow, the gauge above the directional indicator is the main signal strength indicator. All those smaller gauges above it show signal strength at different frequencies, but you only need to worry about this main signal strength indicator for now. Watch that needle, if you see it jump, there is a significant sound out there in the water, and you will want to focus on it, listen to it, and try to figure out what it is.â€

â€œLet us seeâ€¦â€ Hemi turned the direction dial slowly. About a quarter of the way around the strength indicator dial moved up a little and wavered there. â€œSo see by the needle that there is something to hear in this direction. What do you hear in your headset now?â€

Cassandra listened, her eyes watching the signal strength indicator needle wavering like a humming bird feeding. It was moving in response to another kind of white noise; higher pitched than the subâ€™s engines, which she could still hear rumbling in the lower frequencies. This sound was familiar, a washing, churning sound with an occasional rumble mixed inâ€¦ She smiled, â€œitâ€™s breaking surf isnâ€™t it?â€

â€œCorrect! There is a small atoll a few miles in that direction and waves are breaking on its shore. Letâ€™s see what else is out there.â€ Around the directional needle went, and Hemi slowed it, and stopped with the strength indicator needle throbbing slightly, like it had a pulse.

Cassandra closed her eyes. In her headphones she could hear a distant clicking, slow and regular. The clicks had a strange kind of richness to them. They bounced around the underwater landscape, and she could hear not just the clicks but also the echoes of the clicks. The dark world out there lit up in her mind, and she remembered storybooks about sea life from not so long ago when she was a child. â€œIs that the sound dolphins make?â€

â€œVery good! Dolphins use active sonar, bouncing sounds off underwater objects to locate them. They are much better at it than we are. Did you notice that you could hear the dolphins in one ear slightly before the other?â€

Cassandra nodded again.

â€œThat is because the sonar uses a couple of sets of microphones, one on the front of the boat, and one at the rear. Sound coming in hits one microphone before the other, and the sonar rig puts the difference into the earphones for you. With practice, you can use the difference in how long it takes to estimate how far away a contact is. For instance, I can tell you these dolphins are about a third of a nautical mile away. That only works if the contact is close enough that we can hear the difference though. If you think about it: a contact that is farther away will send out a sound that will be murky enough by the time it gets to us to hit both the microphones on the bow of the Prospect and the stern at basically the same time. Itâ€™s not unlike the way the stars in the sky look like they are on a flat plane even though thereâ€™s vast differences in the distance they might be from us.â€

â€œOK, ya, that makes sense,â€ said Cassandra, picturing the sound waves bouncing off the boat in her head.

Hemi smiled. â€œMiss Cassandra, you may have a career ahead of you. Keep practicing until we surface and we start the diesels later tonight. You will not be able to hear anything after that.â€

â€œOK Hemi. Thanks.â€

Hemi left her there listening to the dolphins and climbed up next to Percy in the control room.

â€œHowâ€™d she do?â€ asked Percy.

â€œWe may have a pair of ears yet.â€

â€œThat would be a nice fucking change. Most of these meatheads are OK at rudimentary steering, but theyâ€™re fuckinâ€™ useless on sonar.â€

âŸ

A few hours later the clocks and sun charts coordinated to tell them that it was well after dark on the surface. Percy had the boat come up to periscope depth and she put the scope up to check the surface. Finding an empty black horizon in all directions, she had Gregory blow air into the main ballast tanks from the low-pressure system and raise the Prospect fully up to the surface.

Captain Percyâ€™s standard strategy for a cargo run was to stay underwater and run slow on the batteries during the day, and surface to run on the diesels at night. Running on the diesels meant moving much faster and recharging the shipâ€™s batteries at the same time. Even with all the shipping traffic these days, the oceans were still mostly huge open spaces. A submarine running with no lights on the surface at night was a dark and tiny target, unlikely to be spotted by anyone. The main risk was being tracked by radar â€” on the surface they created a fairly strong radar signature. But at the same time, they ran their own radar receiver. If anyone else was tracking the Prospect with radar, the Prospectâ€™s crew would see the signal and know they were there, usually with plenty of time for the Prospect to disappear underwater and change course.

The only other way they might be found is if an Authority ship heard the Prospectâ€™s rumbling diesels on sonar. But to do that they would have to be within ten or twenty nautical miles of the Prospect. Not an impossible scenario, but somewhat unlikely on any normal night of a cargo run.

Captain Percy also always kept going one more ancient backup system for spotting any trouble early: she put someone up in the lookout ring with binoculars. As soon as the deck was above the surface of the water, Percy and Hemi went up through the hatch in the control room and climbed to the bridge at the top of the sail. Percy had the radar mast raised, which had two lookout rings mounted to it, one on either side, and called Owen up. As he came up onto the bridge she handed him binoculars and pointed to the lookout rings. Owen kept climbing.

Percy looked at Hemi. â€œBe glad you donâ€™t have to do fucking lookout duty anymore.â€

â€œI am,â€ said Hemi, â€œI remember it well. At night, you are just standing up there in the wind, like you are swimming through pure blackness. Your mind starts to play tricks on you when you most need to keep your mind clear. It is a young personâ€™s job.â€

â€œReliable young people, anyway,â€ said Percy. â€œHey down there in the control room,â€ she shouted through the hatch, â€œyou can start the diesels.â€

There was a moment more of the quiet of the water sloshing down the length of the hull pushed by the electric motors before the diesels deep in the belly of the Prospect hissed, coughed, and fired. Black smoke streamed out behind the sail. The vibration of the engines carried up up through the deck and shook the soles of their feet.

Hemi called down to ask for their new speed and to confirm the heading. He marked the answers down carefully on his ever-present clipboard.

â€œI heard that some boats like the Prospect are being fitted with snorkels now,â€ said Hemi.

â€œThatâ€™s what theyâ€™re calling those masts you can raise for feeding oxygen to the diesels while underwater, right?â€

â€œYes. The diesels exhaust out of them too. A boat with a snorkel never has to come up to the surface, you can recharge the batteries from periscope depth.â€

â€œWe should look into installing one at some point. Maybe after this job. It seems like it would be worth the investment. The nighttime surface runs are starting to require too much care and caution for me to feel safe.â€

â€œThe funny thing,â€ Hemi continued, â€œis I also heard that a snorkeling diesel is actually louder on sonar than one running on the surface.â€

â€œYouâ€™re fucking kidding?â€

Hemi looked at her incredulously â€” he was hardly ever kidding. â€œApparently with the whole boat underwater more of the sound of the running engines goes into the water. On the surface, some of it escapes into the air. Nobody expected that when they came up with the idea of the snorkel, but the boats out in the ocean were suddenly detectable 40 miles off or so on sonar.â€

â€œSo once again the newfangled technology doesnâ€™t solve a fucking problem, it just creates more options for a captain to have to make fucking decisions about.â€ Percy spat.

â€œIt is certainly not a job I would ever want. I prefer a measure of certainty in my work.â€

Percy lit a cheroot. Hemi looked up at the dark gray sky, mostly obscured by cloud cover.

â€œHowâ€™s the navigation going?â€ Percy exhaled a long stream of smoke that was caught up by the wind and braided into the diesel exhaust behind them.

â€œI have been keeping very close track of our time, direction and speed, as usual. But you know my track is only as good as guesswork can be. If these clouds break up tonight, and we get some stars, I would like to fix our position on the chart. When is the rendezvous with Shakes?â€

â€œAt dawn. It will certainly be easier if we know where we are with some precision.â€

â€œAnd if we can rely on Shakes to know where he isâ€¦â€

The night ground on with the unvarying drone of the diesel engines always under the foot of any crew member on deck and relentlessly surrounding anyone below decks. Since the diesel engines of the Prospect were just generators that created electricity to charge the batteries that powered the electric motors that actually propelled the boat, they were always run at the same optimum-efficiency speed for spinning the generators. Even when the boat changed speed, the all-consuming hum around them never changed in pitch or amplitude. For the crew at the controls, with no depth to control while they were on the surface and a steady course, there was almost nothing to do. The needles of the rows of gauges all stood steadfastly at their marks.

Percy knew that this was the hardest part of the job â€” remaining always ready to take action when there was absolutely nothing to do. The crew had to stay focused on the job during hours and hours of virtually no sensory input at all. It was far too easy to fall asleep at the controls, or let oneâ€™s mind wander off to a place where everything was not just a grime-coated gray accompanied by a background of lush and never-changing noise that managed to be the exact auditory equivalent to the bland color that surrounded them.

She put the crew on rest rotations. Every three hours three of them would get three hours off. This kept two people in the control room at all times, one on lookout, and one at the radar/sonar station. The off-duty crew were free to spend their time on deck if they wanted. But since there was little to see up there but a black horizon tapped firmly against a dark gray one, most of the crew came back down after a few minutes and ended up in their rack sleeping. Except for Bastian: he wrapped his long thin form in a rubber foul-weather slicker to keep the wind off and lay out on the forward deck, apparently finding sleep there as easily as warm puppy.

âŸ

Hours later, sometime during the third rotation, Hemi found Cassandra in the navigation and sonar compartment, listening intently to the sonar with the headphones on and her eyes closed.

Hemi tapped her on the shoulder, and she jumped a little before smiling when she saw it was him and pulling back a headphone.

â€œArenâ€™t you supposed to be in your rack?â€ Hemi said.

â€œI volunteered to take two rotations in a row â€” to keep the rotations even for everyone elseâ€¦and since Iâ€™m new.â€

â€œAre you hearing anything?â€ Hemi asked.

â€œNo.Â I try to imagine my mind going out into the water to listen to whatâ€™s around us, but I canâ€™t get past the sound of the diesels.â€

â€œSonar is extremely limited with the engines running. Butâ€¦â€ Hemi flipped some filter switches on the sonar control board, and adjusted some tone dials. These were familiar settings he used when he was on sonar while the engines were running. â€œTry it like that.â€

Cassandra set the headphones back into their comfortable position on her ears, and listened for a minute. â€œThatâ€™s much better. Itâ€™s like the engines are at least not distracting my attention.â€ She made some notes on a pad of the settings Hemi had made.

â€œYou are keeping an eye on radar too, right? That is actually maybe more important while we are on the surface.â€

â€œYup. Owen showed me what to look for. The radarâ€¦ has not done anything at all.â€

â€œThat is good.â€

â€œI didnâ€™t realize when I agreed to come on board that this job would be so mind-numbingâ€¦ and boring.â€

â€œThat is what makes it so hard, and why only a certain type of person makes it as a submariner. I think on land there is something of a perception that it is this glorious job, where you are out from under the thumb of Authorities, free to pursue your own career, and helping to make world commerce go around. The people on land know it is dangerous, and that gets mixed into the legend of who a submariner is. But in reality, the people who make good submariners are the ones who can handle being in a cramped space for days on end with no changes in their environment at all and still manage to keep their mind sharp enough to snap into action when a situation presents itself. It is not a job that is an expression of physical acuity. It is a job that puts your mental toughness to the test.â€

â€œI certainly donâ€™t have much to offer in physical strengthâ€¦â€ said Cassandra.

â€œPeople on land think it is a job for tough guys. We are always getting men looking for jobs on submarines. Men who look like, well, like me. Hefty guys with a lot of muscles. And some of those guys are fine. But Captain Percy and I have realized over the years that the mental toughness we need is not correlated to physical toughness. We hire people who we anticipate might have that mental fortitude, at least when we have an option in who we can hire. And we find that mental toughness in all kinds of people. It is not just me and Percy, most of the people who actually work in the submarine cargo industry these days look for that quality in all types. The Authority subs are still full of big men, but the commercial subs are a pretty diverse crowd of workers.â€

â€œThe depot was full of big menâ€¦â€

â€œYou know how that happens? Those men go looking for work on submarines thinking it is a good job for a strong fellow. But they find out they can not handle the mental strain, and they wash out. They end up working the next job out from what the center of what they went looking for: servicing submarines instead of working on them.â€

â€œAhâ€¦â€ she said, her eyes widening as large piece of her world that didnâ€™t quite make sense before fell into place in her mind.

â€œUnlike work on land, there are few regulations or rules controlling our work out here. The job has pure evolutionary forces in play. The only people doing the work are the ones who can. Everyone else goes home, back to their Authorities, and policies, and networks of contacts. On land you get a job based on what you look like, and who you know. Out here, you get a job if you can do the job. We do not care who you know, where you came from, or what you look like.â€

A smile cracked across Cassandraâ€™s face. â€œThatâ€™s why you hired me?â€

â€œNo, no no. Captain Percy hired you because she was desperate for someone to sit on sonar. But you should know that you have just as good a chance at doing this job well as any other person. Andâ€¦ you have done well on your first day working.â€

Cassandra nodded. â€œI want to learn as much as I can.â€ She paused, thinking about her future. â€œWhat are you up to at this hour of the night Hemi?â€

â€œI am catching up on navigation. I have to do this every few hours. Come over here and look at the chart.â€

Cassandra hung the sonar headphones on the hook and joined Hemi at the navigation table. She looked at the big chart, and the dotted line marking their course from the depot island, and the little x marking their current position. â€œHow do you know where we are?â€

â€œHonestly, it is mostly just a guess. I keep track of our speed and direction very carefully. Then I just plot that onto the chart based on how long we have been traveling. That is called dead-reckoning. If the chart is accurate and there are not too many mitigating factors, like, say, a strong current that I can not account for, then we know roughly where we are and that we will not run into anything.â€

â€œWhat happens if there is a strong currently the pushes you off course and you donâ€™t realize it?â€

â€œThat is why we need to sometimes fix our position. If we pass by an island or other feature that we see while on the surface or with the periscope, and that feature is on the chart, then we know where we are. Sometimes there are undersea features that we can hear on the sonar, or we know are there by changes we read in the gauge that measures how far down the bottom is. If those are on the chart, we can fix our position that way. Normally, we do not have to be super-precise â€” the ocean is large and mostly empty water. It is also easier this early in a run â€” I know exactly where we started from at the depot, so our position should not be too far off. But we need to rendezvous with Shakes at dawn, and being precise about our location will help that go more smoothly. So I am going up on the bridge to get a fix by the stars. Want to join me? If the stars are out, it might be worth the trip up the ladder.â€

â€œIs it OK for me to leave the radar?â€

â€œJust for a few minutes. Make sure to check it as soon as you come back down.â€

They climbed up through the control room and up the interior ladders of the sail to the bridge. Owen was back in the lookout ring above them and greeted them when their heads shadowed the red light coming up from the open hatch, happy to have something to break the monotony of being on lookout.

Overhead the clouds had blown off leaving a clear night sky with no moon. Hemi often remarked that it occurred far more often than seemed statistically probable that the Prospect surfaced and he came out on deck to find a low, blanketing cloud cover. He could hardly recall the last time they surfaced to a clear sky and his deeply-rational self was challenged by the sense that being on the open surface was in fact natureâ€™s opportunity to oppress them. He had begun to prefer being submerged, where instead they had control over the pressure and depth of the atmospheres laying upon them.

But not this night. The sky was clear from one horizon to the other, and the stars glowed in their visible tens-of-thousands, their appreciable numbers a heuristic suggesting the reality of the uncountable multiples of billions of other stars that existed invisibly in the universe above them. With no light over the horizon, the stars came right down to the surface of the water in every direction, infinity compressed to a perfectly smooth dome that lay over them.

â€œWow,â€ said Cassandra.

â€œYes, thatâ€™s the marinerâ€™s privilege,â€ said Hemi. â€œAnd the lucky submariner occasionally gets to dip in as well.â€

Hemi took out his sextant, clipboard, star charts, and graphs. He took sightings on three or four known stars, measuring their precise height above the horizon. He scratched a number of notes onto the clipboard with a pencil.

â€œHow does that thing work?â€ Cassandra asked.

â€œThis is a sextant. It measures how far above the horizon a particular star or the sun is. That will let me fix our position on the chart. If you are interested, I can train you how to use it. But not tonight.â€

Cassandra nodded.

â€œUnlike mariners, the submariner does not often have the luxury of visual references to find their place in the world,â€ Hemi continued, â€œwe wander under the ocean, feeling our way by sound. And every once in a while poke our head up to secure our location in the swirling mass by judging ourselves against the stars.â€

â€œThatâ€™s poetic,â€ said Owen, listening to their conversation from the lookout ring.

Hemi smiled, â€œand just a little bit of a clichÃ©,â€ he said more loudly for Owenâ€™s benefit. â€œI find a touch of the poetic gives some much-needed meaning to this black and gray metal world of ours. But if you let it go to your head, it could keep you from making the clear-minded assessments of situations that are necessary to remain alive as a submariner.â€ Hemi took a sighting of another star and marked its altitude down on his clipboard. â€œOK Cassandra. Back to your radar scope. I need to make some minor course adjustments in the control room.â€

Hemi and Cassandra climbed back down into the Prospect leaving Owen alone to occupy the center point on a circular field of blackness under the perfect half-sphere of stars.

âŸ

Early in the pre-dawn hours, Bastian was up in the lookout ring when the sky began to lighten in the east, graying out the stars in that direction and creating an echo of light on the black disk of the ocean. When Bastian could see his hands in the gloom in front of him, he climbed down to the bridge and cupping one hand around his mouth shouted down to the control room that it might be time to dive.

Captain Percy climbed up to join Bastian on the bridge and looked around for a few minutes. She took some long breaths â€” the last of the fresh air before the next twelve hours or so below deck â€” and then told Bastian to follow her back down into the sub.

They buttoned up the Prospect and, when all the hatches showed green lights on the board in the control room, they shut down the diesels and dove the boat to 50 meters. After fixing their position earlier in the evening, Hemi had slept his three hours, and then returned immediately to the control room. Now that they were submerged again, he wanted to take the boat in a new direction as a precaution against the small chance that anyone had been tracking their course on the surface without their being aware of it. With the cargo they were hauling, Hemi felt there was no reason not use to every stealth maneuver they had.

After they had leveled off, he had them bring the boat hard about to starboard. This was backtracking a bit, but they were now aimed directly at the rendezvous point for the Gnat, which they would reach in another two hours at their current speed.

Those two hours remained nearly silent and uneventful. Everyone had low early-morning energy and no one felt like much of a conversationalist after a long night with short sleep. Though the social situation was improved by Gregory bringing up the first pot of coffee and passing around tin mugs to the crew in the sonar compartment and the control room.

They cruised to the rendezvous point, and then came up to 30 meters of depth. They shut down the electric motors entirely, and Hemi trimmed the boat until it sat hovering perfectly still and silent in the water.

Cassandra was just waking up from her sleep rotation, and groggily making her way from the crew quarters to the sonar compartment where she found Hemi. He handed her a tin cup full of sweetened black coffee.

â€œTime to get back on sonar Cassandra. We have reached the spot where we are supposed to rendezvous with Shakes. I need you to listen for his boat. It is quite a small boat, so it may be challenging to hear. But since we have got the Prospect completely shut down you will have total silence. If you hear Shakes â€” or anything else in the water â€” come get me. I will be in the galley. The rest of the crew is going on break while there is nothing to do, so it is all you right now.â€

â€œThat makes this sound importantâ€¦ you trust me with this?â€

â€œIt is good practice for you, and the worst that could happen is you miss him and we are a little delayed in the rendezvous. I would be happier if we got moving again soon though, soâ€¦ try not to miss him if he goes past.â€

â€œOK Hemi.â€ Cassandra sat down at the sonar rig, put the headphones on, and took a sip of her coffee before passing the mics around in a full circle to get settled and oriented.

Hemi went off to the galley with his clipboard and notes, and the rest of the crew hit the racks to catch up on much-needed sleep. The Prospect was left dark and absolutely silent.

Cassandra turned the directional control of the mics slowly around. She completed another full 360 circle, and then came back the other way. Her eyes closed and she could see the sounds in the water coming towards the Prospect. The water had slightly different qualities in different directions, so after a few times around she could tell generally which way the microphones were pointing without looking at the directional indicator. When they were forward towards the bow, she could hear the bilge water sloshing in the lowest parts of the ship. Towards the stern, she could hear clearly without the annoying interruption of the propeller sound that was always in that direction while the electric motors were running.

The Prospect was currently at its absolute maximum sonar listening capacity, but there was nothing out there. The ocean was completely empty in every direction. Cassandra focused her mind and kept it out in the water. Every time she felt some subject other than sonar intruding on her consciousness, she took a deep breath and forced her mind back out into the water.

It was incredibly tiring work.

Two hours later, there had still been no sign of Shakes. Captain Percy could never sleep for long, and so was soon back in the control room with a cup of coffee from the galley, smoking and making small adjustments to the trim of the boat. Each of these adjustments was accompanied by a brief rush of water or air through the piping of the ship. And each time this happened Cassandra got completely distracted for a few frustrating moments. Cassandra did not yet realize that the sonar operator could, in some instances, have some authority over even the captain on a submarine and request silence be maintained.

Another hour went by. Cassandra thought she was starting to crack. She considered asking Hemi to take over. She was worried that somehow Shakes had sneaked past her in his little sub. That she had missed him and screwed up her first real job. Rationally, she knew that was unlikely though. She pushed herself to keep listening to the silence.

Then, far off their port side, she heard an engine in the water. It was not like the other sea craft she had heard thus far in her limited experience on sonar. It had a continuous popping sound, like a machine gun being fired off in the distance, accompanied by a low-frequency roar.

â€œCaptain Percy!â€ Cassandra called up to the control room where Percy still sat fiddling with the controls to her boat. â€œI hear something.â€

Percy slid down the ladder and picked up the second sonar headset and put it on. Cassandra, rolled the mics back and forth across the direction of the contact, and settled them in on the strongest signal.

â€œIs that Captain Shakes?â€ Cassandra asked doubtfully.

â€œThat canâ€™t be fucking Shakes, it sounds like a supertanker or an aircraft carrier or something. Go get Hemi. I think he should hear this.â€

Cassandra went off to the galley leaving Percy listening to the contact. She came back with Hemi holding a tin cup with the dregs of cold coffee in the bottom. He slipped the headphones on and stood there, his coffee cup tilting around his fingers, staring at the gauges on the sonar and watching them bobble up and down. He flipped some filters on, and listened again.

â€œWell,â€ Hemi said, â€œthat is strange. It does sound like a tanker or something big just from sheer volume. But it is moving very fast, too fast for a big shipâ€¦â€ He paused listening again. â€œIt is closer now, and I can hear the prop revolutionsâ€¦ the frequencies are all wrong. The prop is spinning too fast, and sounds small, not like a big ship screw.â€

â€œShakes was planning to modify the Gnat to be louder â€” you think that could be what his boat sounds like now?â€ Percy asked.

â€œIf that is Shakes, the job has been overdoneâ€¦â€

â€œReally? You think itâ€™s fuckinâ€™ possible Shakes overdid it, do you?â€ Percy rolled her eyes. â€œMaybe instead of the sound of the Gnat masquerading for the Prospect, the Gnat will just drown out everything in a ten mile radius.â€

â€œI justâ€¦â€ Hemi started, â€œjust cannot believe that such a small boat couldâ€¦â€ he paused listening again. â€œNo, I am more sure of it now. The more detail I can hear, the more it makes sense that it is a very very loud, small boat, not a big ship. Though he does have it tuned so low that from a distance anyone who is not skilled on sonar might easily be fooled into thinking the contact is displacing an enormous amount of water. Good job with the identification Cassandra.â€

Cassandra held onto a large and genuine smile.

â€œOK then. So now what do we do?â€ asked Percy. â€œIf we were on the surface, Iâ€™d try to raise him on the radio. But I arranged with Shakes to rendezvous at depth, so no one sees us. Iâ€™d hate to blow our cover by surfacing now.â€

â€œI do not know,â€ said Hemi. â€œThe contact is well out of range of ship-to-ship. I would guess something like still 20 nautical miles off or so. We could hit it with active.â€

â€œIf it turns out youâ€™re wrong and the contact is actually that sub with the ram tearing its way towards us, then an active ping will be like knocking on their hatch and telling them exactly where we are.â€ Percy paused. â€œWe have the advantage of being completely hidden at the moment. I hate to just hand that away.â€

Hemi shrugged. â€œThat is why I leave the decision to you.â€

Percy considered her options. â€œYou are fairly certain itâ€™s Shakes?â€ she asked Hemi.

â€œI am fairly certain that contact is not the big ship it initially sounded like,â€ said Hemi.

â€œFuck it. Ping it.â€

â€œOK. Cassandra, remember I mentioned â€˜activeâ€™ sonar during your training session? I am going to use that now. Follow what I do.â€ He powered up the active sonar unit. â€œPassive sonar is like listening quietly in a dark room to figure out where other people might be standing. Active sonar is like quickly turning a bright light on and then off again so you can see the exact location of the people in the room. The principles behind it are much more sophisticated than passive. But it is easy enough to operate.â€ He set the direction indicator to point towards the contact. â€œPush the PING button Cassandra.â€

She held her small finger out flat, so as not to let her long fingernail get in the way, and crushed the button home. Even without the sonar headsets they could hear the smooth round ringing sound of the ping echo through the hull and spread out into the water around them. A few seconds later the active unit calculated and displayed the range and direction to the contact.

â€œThe active sonar figures out precisely where your contact is by calculating how long it takes for that ping sound to bounce back from the target,â€ Hemi said, pointing to the readout on the active sonar unit. â€œThat is useful if you have to do something like aim and fire a torpedo. But since the Prospect does not have torpedoes, we do not often have reason to use it.â€

â€œThe active ping also tells the target exactly where we are,â€ added Percy. â€œNormally, we would not want to do that â€” never use the active sonar without an explicit instruction from me or Hemi â€” but assuming this contact is Shakesâ€¦â€ she looked at Hemi, â€œthen we just deliberately let them know exactly where we are by hitting them with that active ping.â€

â€œWe shall see what the contact does now,â€ said Hemi, putting the sonar headset back on.

Within a minute of the Prospectâ€™s ping, the contact went silent.

â€œTheyâ€™re gone?â€ Cassandra asked, still listening to the other headset.

â€œThey have shut down their engine,â€ Hemi said, â€œwhich does not tell us anything.â€

â€œWell how the fuck were they supposed to respond?â€ Percy asked Hemi.

â€œCan he just ping us back?â€ asked Cassandra.

â€œI am not sure the Gnat has an active sonar system like that,â€ said Hemi. â€œWe could ping them again? It would let them know we are not going anywhere.â€ He looked over at Percy.

â€œAnd then what? Whatâ€™s the full fuckinâ€™ plan here Hemi?â€ she asked.

â€œWell, without surfacing, I think we wait until he moves into ship-to-ship range. Then we can confirm it is Shakes over ship-to-ship radio.â€

â€œA quarter of a nautical mile? If itâ€™s someone who wants to do unpleasant things to us instead of Shakes, thatâ€™s awfully fucking close.â€

â€œIf they want to do unpleasant things, they are likely to begin long before reaching ship-to-ship range,â€ said Hemi. â€œI advise we ping them again. If the contact does anything that seems suspicious, we will move off from this spot â€” quietly.â€

â€œâ€¦Alright,â€ said Percy. â€œFuckinâ€™ ping â€™em again. What do I care, itâ€™s just my boat and all our lives.â€

Hemi caught Cassandraâ€™s eye and pointed to the PING button. She reached out and pressed it again. Another resonant ping left the Prospect and soared through the water. The range and direction displayed on the active sonar unit.

â€œSee Cassandra, it was like they were invisible while they were being silent, but bouncing the ping off them let us know they are still there. â€¦And they know we are still here.â€

Cassandra nodded with one hand on an earpiece. She listened quietly for a minute. Then: â€œI think I hear something.â€

Hemi listened closely. â€œOK, the contact is running on electric motor now. And I can tell by the pitch that itâ€™s definitely a small craft moving quicklyâ€¦ towards us.â€ Hemi listened for a moment longer. â€œIt is definitely the Gnat, I recognize it now.â€

â€œThank fuckinâ€™ hell,â€ said Percy, â€œthat was ridiculous Hemi. Weâ€™ve got to work out a better way of communicating with the Gnat if weâ€™re going to keep working with that guy. We canâ€™t be pinging every tanker that goes over us hoping itâ€™s actually our tiny submarine friend.â€

â€œIâ€™ll talk to Shakes about it when we get him on board,â€ said Hemi.

âŸ

Within an hour, Shakes voice lit up the ship-to-ship radio in the control room. â€œBreak. Break. This is the mighty Gnat. Were those fuckinâ€™ ear-splitting pings coming from the folks Iâ€™m looking for?â€

Hemi climbed the ladder to the control room and took the mic from the overhead radio. â€œIndeed Gnat. This is the Prospect and we are glad to know now that we were not pinging an Authority battleship.â€

â€œAh,â€ said Shakes, â€œso my subterfugal modifications were effective? Wait till you see what I fuckinâ€™ did Hemi. Youâ€™re going to love it.â€

Hemi smiled into the mic. â€œSounds good Captain Shakes. You did not break off your mating collar while making those modifications did you?â€

â€œNope. Itâ€™s still riding with fucking pride atop the Gnatâ€™s sail. Mating with the Prospect should be at least as smooth as last time.â€

â€œI hope it does not go that badly,â€ said Hemi. â€œOK, we will put the Prospect in gear, and drive forward slowly. Just like last time, you can come up underneath, and put the Gnat on the mating collar.â€

â€œRoger that. Butâ€¦ youâ€™re going to have to come up shallower. I might have more confidence than I used to, but I still donâ€™t want to push the Gnat as deep as you are now if I donâ€™t fuckinâ€™ hafta.â€

Captain Percy had been listening to the conversation from below at the navigation station. Now she climbed up to the control room to sort out the details of this maneuver with Hemi.

Hemi caught her eye while she was still on the ladder. â€œShakes needs us to come shallow.â€

â€œHow shallow? Iâ€™d prefer to keep her as deep as possible.â€

â€œI believe the Gnatâ€™s maximum depth was around 30 meters â€” according to Shakesâ€™ estimate that was unchallenged by anything like an engineering background.â€

â€œCan we do it with the Prospect at 20 meters?â€ she asked.

â€œI suspect so, thatâ€™s about how deep we had it at the depot.â€ Hemi thumbed the mic on the ship-to-ship. â€œCaptain Shakes, what if we make the Prospectâ€™s keel 20 meters down. Can you do the mating at that depth?â€

â€œSurely,â€ Shakes voice crackled in reply, â€œBut remember that while the Gnat is attached, you can not go any fucking deeper. Beyond 30 meters or so and youâ€™ll crush the Gnat and, you know, probably flood the fuckinâ€™ Prospect as well â€” not that Iâ€™ll be giving two shits about your ugly barge after you beer-canned my baby.â€

â€œI got you Captain Shakes. 20 meters maximum depth it is.â€

They carried out the maneuver without incident. Shakes brought the Gnat up under the Prospect and connected to the mating collar. When he popped the hatch, Chips was there waiting for him, just like last time.

â€œAh fuck-ya Captain Shakes. At least I didnâ€™t have to weld your fuckinâ€™ boat back together to get ya on board this fuckinâ€™ time.â€

â€œGood to see you again too Chips. Iâ€™ll have you know my boat has been adjusted and tuned to an absolute precision-meisterâ€™s peak of fuckinâ€™ performance. The Gnat is now faster, more maneuverable, and louder than any other boat of its size and displacement.â€

â€œAh, yer the first fucker Iâ€™ve ever fucking met who is proud to have a loud fucking submarine Captain Shakes.â€

They made their way up to the galley, where Chips parted with Shakes to continue working on the efficiencies of her own engines in the engine room. Shakes poured some stale coffee from the pot into a mug and sat down.

Hemi and Percy joined Shakes in the galley as soon as they got the Prospect settled back on course, leaving Gregory and Bastian at the controls. The boat would spend the remaining hours of daylight running underwater. Hemi did not neglect to warn Gregory to keep a close eye on the depth and ballast control panel and not let the boat dive any deeper than they already were while the Gnat was attached.

â€œSo Captain Shakes,â€ said Percy, settling next to him with her own stale cup of coffee, â€œyou made it out of the depot without causing a problem?â€

â€œWellâ€¦ there was in fact a little fuckinâ€™â€¦ drama. Iâ€™m sure you heard some of it.â€

â€œWe got a tip to leave before anything very dramatic happened,â€ said Hemi.

â€œSo I gathered from your note Captain Percy. Unfortunately I was in the middle of some work on the Gnat when I got that note, otherwise I would have left right then myself. The Gnatâ€™s engine was in fuckinâ€™ pieces â€” I was putting a new exhaust in that I got in a deal in one of the parts shops on the exchange floor after I had got my cargo transshipped. So I was stuck on the dock when that fuckinâ€™ Authority sub arrived.â€

â€œWhat sub? Was it the sub with the ram?â€ Hemi asked.

â€œWell, I couldnâ€™t very well see whether it had a ram from inside the docking bay, could I? But I heard the name of the boat was the Grackle, that mean anything to yâ€™all?â€

â€œFrom the Northern Points Authority?â€ asked Percy.

â€œThatâ€™s what the dock workers told me. How did you know that?â€

â€œMiss Mai, who gave us this job, suggested that might be the identity of the sub with the ram.â€

â€œWhat did you do to the Northern Points that would send them after you?â€

â€œNothing! Fuckinâ€™ Nothing. Iâ€™ve never been there. Miss Mai suggests larger shifts happening in the world that could affect our innocent little business here, and the Grackle may be a symptom of those global-scale changes,â€ said Percy.

â€œWell then. That boat docked and unloaded a bunch of big fucking goons. Bigger even than those who worked at the depot. Or, better fuckinâ€™ armed and armored at least. The goons tore through the whole fuckinâ€™ depot checking papers at every slip with a sub docked, questioning every person they saw in the docking bay.â€

â€œIncluding you?â€ Percy asked.

â€œIncluding me. That was no trouble, Iâ€™ve got quality fucking papers and stories to put off any Authority inspection long enough for me to tiptoe away. But hereâ€™s a thing: they was specifically asking about your boatâ€

â€œThey asked about the Prospect â€” by name?â€ Percy was horrified that any Authority would know the name of her boat at all, never mind going around asking about it.

â€œIndeed. A couple of those goons stood over the slip to the Gnat and asked me if I knew anything about a boat named the Prospect; small lady captain, big fuckinâ€™ first mate.â€

â€œI assume you did not have any further information for them?â€ Hemi asked.

â€œOf course fuckinâ€™ not. But that didnâ€™t matter. By the time they got far enough down the dock to talk to me it was just perfunctory-like questioning. They had already found out from other sub crews that you had definitely been thereâ€¦ And that you left with a load of magnetic warheads.â€

â€œThey asked you about our fucking cargo too, eh?â€ said Percy.

â€œYa. Fortunately, they didnâ€™t seem to know anything about me coming in with you. I guess the other sub crews were afraid enough of Authority goons with guns to give up someone who isnâ€™t around, but arenâ€™t such cowards as to go so far as pointing at someone they can actually fuckinâ€™ see in the same space.â€

Hemi picked up a spoon and stirred his coffee.

Captain Percy lit a cheroot. â€œShit,â€ she said, â€œif they know weâ€™ve got what-could-be-considered-by-certain-parties-as weapons parts on board, seems like they could take that as a fuckinâ€™ license to shoot to sink if they find us, rather than merely demanding we surface for an inspection.â€

â€œOh,â€ said Shakes after a pause, â€œI didnâ€™t tell you the best fuckinâ€™ part yetâ€¦ So after they finish questioning me, I discreetly â€” and as quickly as I could â€” started prepping the Gnat to leave. â€œHereâ€™s the good fucking part: while heâ€™s up there on the exchange floor, the watertight bulkhead between the docking bay and the upper levels goes into an emergency-close procedure. You know, the whole shebang â€” the klaxon is blaring, the red lights are spinning. The fucking Authority goons start running around in a panic, probably most of them think the docking bay is flooding, hell I thought that myself for a minute.â€

â€œFuckinâ€™ wow,â€ said Percy half-grinning as she exhaled smoke.

â€œFuck yeah. The meat shields werenâ€™t much less panicked at that though â€” because half their fuckinâ€™ muscle and their fuckinâ€™ commander were now separated from them by half a meter of air-tight steel doors!

â€œSo I wasnâ€™t going to miss this wonderful opportunity of confusion â€” I dumped whatever I could find laying around on the dock down into the Gnat, buttoned the boat up, and took the fuck off right then. Ran on battery as far as I could, then put the rest of the exhaust back together. Fortunately the diesel fired up no fucking problem and I made my way here.â€

â€œHmm,â€ said Hemi, â€œwhom do you suppose was willing to anger them further by closing the watertight bulkhead?â€

â€œMy guess,â€ said Shakes, â€œis that it was that dock boss lady. She was the first one the Authority goons questioned, of course, and she didnâ€™t look very fuckinâ€™ happy about it afterwards.â€

â€œTough as she looks, I guess,â€ said Percy.

â€œThat watertight bulkhead did not seem like the kind of thing that was opened and closed at the drop of a fuckinâ€™ hat,â€ said Shakes. â€œI suspect it delayed that Authority sub leaving by a couple of hours, all told. â€œWhich brings up another thing I wanted to ask you about Captain Shakes,â€ said Hemi, â€œthat boat of yours certainly isâ€¦ loud now.â€

â€œFuck yeah! I told you I put in a new exhaust. Straight pipe. Wedged it right up against the hull so the sound goes direct out into the fuckinâ€™ water. And that torque is converted to unbelievably fast prop speeds.â€

â€œAnd a fast prop and new exhaust mean exceptional noise,â€ said Hemi.

â€œIâ€™d say just about the loudest sub in the fuckinâ€™ water!â€ said Shakes proudly. â€œâ€˜Cept maybe some of those old coastal tug subs. That was the fuckinâ€™ plan, right Captain Percy? The Gnat runs loud and fast interference for the Prospect.â€

â€œYes,â€ said Percy, â€œthough I was sort of expecting we could make the Gnat sound like another big submarine, not an ocean liner.â€

â€œThe fuckinâ€™ louder, the fuckinâ€™ better, I fuckinâ€™ figured,â€ said Shakes, popping a wad of dried green leaves into his cheek. â€œOh! I almost forgot: the other modification I made to the Gnat: I got a fuckinâ€™ pigeon.â€

â€œA pigeon?â€ asked Hemi. â€œI have never heard of that. Some new kind of sonar unit?â€

â€œNo no, like an actual fuckinâ€™ pigeon-bird. A homing pigeon. Goes by the name of Herschel.â€

â€œOh, so you got a petâ€¦â€ said Percy, â€œto keep you company during those long hours alone aboard the Gnat. To keep you from going crazyâ€¦ er?â€

â€œNaw, Herschelâ€™s not a pet, I told ya â€” heâ€™s a fuckinâ€™ upgrade to the Gnat! See I got him from a guy on the dock. Heâ€™s specially trained to look for his home roost on a submarine on the surface of the ocean. His roost is on the Gnat now, and Iâ€™ve been taking care of him. â€œUmm. Why would we use a pigeon instead of, say, the radio?â€

â€œWell, I realized that with the modifications I was making to the engine, the Gnat is now so loud inside that I canâ€™t hear the radio while the diesel is running. â€œA pigeonâ€¦â€ said Percy. â€œSeems fuckinâ€™ ridiculous to me.â€

â€œSylvia, this pigeon goes a long way towards addressing the problem we had with communicating with Shakes. Captain Percy rolled her eyes. â€œWhatever. Donâ€™t ever say Iâ€™m a captain who isnâ€™t willing to give new technology a fucking try. Weâ€™ll take the pigeon aboard as our eighth crew member on a trial basis. Captain Shakes: how about a meal?â€

â€œSounds good. But I need to take a shit first. Whereâ€™s the head on this boat?â€

â€œYou havenâ€™t used the Prospectâ€™s head yet?â€

â€œNaw. I prefer to waft my bum in the fortifying fresh air of the surface, if thatâ€™s an option. But seeing as weâ€™re under right nowâ€¦â€

â€œItâ€™s on the middle deck, aft of the crew quarters. Be careful. Make sure you read all the instructions. Itâ€™s fucking complicated.â€

â€œAye, itâ€™s been a while since I used the fuckinâ€™ head on a sub. I sank the last sub I took a shit on.â€

Percy decided to assume he was joking.

âŸ

Percy called Gregory down from the control room and sent Owen up to relieve him. Shakes soon joined them in the galley, and scrubbed his grimy hands with salt-water soap and water from the sinkâ€™s sea-water tap.

Gregory fired up the cooking range and soon had canned salmon simmering in a slightly sweet dark sauce with bits of ginger in it. He put a big pot of rice on to steam.

â€œThat smells fuckinâ€™ astonishing Gregory,â€ Shakes said. â€œI eat that canned salmon all the time when Iâ€™m on the Gnat â€” usually just cold and straight from the can though.â€

â€œThatâ€™sâ€¦ pretty fucking foul Captain Shakes,â€ said Gregory from the range, stirring his bits of fish around.

â€œYou know, I always wondered why those salmon cans are tapered like that. Why donâ€™t they just run straight fucking up and down, like all the other cans?â€

â€œActually, now that you mention it Captain Shakes, I always thought that was unusual myself. There has to be 300 cans in the galley, and all of them are perfect cylinders except for the fuckinâ€™ salmon.â€

â€œI wish all cans were tapered,â€ said Shakes. â€œSometimes I knock a stack of cans over on the Gnat and the regular ones will run off under some piece of equipment. Iâ€™m pretty fucking sure thereâ€™s some cans in the bottom of the boat that rolled there years ago and I never saw again. But the taper on the salmon cans makes â€™em roll around in a tight circle. They stay roughly where they fall no matter what the boat is doing and I can pick them right up before they get lost.â€

â€œMaybe salmon manufacturers know mariners and submariners have a lot of salmon on board, and they shape them like that so our seagoing friends donâ€™t lose their precious cans in the corners of ships,â€ Gregory suggested.

Hemi chuckled. â€œIf you want to know the real reason, it is because the salmon canneries are all in remote parts of the North. The cans are shipped up there empty to be filled with fresh-caught northern salmon. The tapered cans let them stack far more cans into the hold of ships, moving the empty cans by nesting them.â€

â€œOh,â€ said Shakes, sounding somewhat disappointed.

In another twenty minutes or so Gregory had steaming piles of rice on their plates smothered in bits of fish and ginger. He stir-fried a couple of boxes of frozen spinach and scooped them onto their plates to supplement the black and white mush with some dark green.

Percy called the rest of the crew in to eat in rotations that always kept one person in the control room and another listening to sonar. Shakes, as usual, ate twice again as much as anyone else.

â€œSweet fuck,â€ he said, â€œif you keep feeding me food I want to eat instead of forcing myself to eat cold shit from cans, Iâ€™m going to get fucking fat.â€ He reclined in his chair, unbuckled his belt, and closed his eyes.

â€œNothing stopping you from equipping your boat with a hot plate Captain Shakes,â€ said Gregory.

Shakes waved his hand in Gregoryâ€™s direction lazily without opening his eyes.

â€œShakes, when you regain yourself from your crapulence,â€ said Hemi, â€œjoin me at the navigation station. I want to make sure you understand our plan for this run.â€

Shakes nodded sleepily as Hemi and Percy headed up to the navigation and sonar compartment.

â€œItâ€™s probably time for more coffee,â€ said Gregory reaching for the pot with the dregs of the previous batch slowly embalming a permanent black-brown stain on the bottom.

âŸ

Shakes joined Hemi and Percy at the navigation table a short while later, somewhat revived by Gregoryâ€™s coffee, and carrying two more tin mugs filled with coffee for Hemi and Percy, which they received gratefully.

â€œHereâ€™s what weâ€™re thinking Captain Shakes,â€ said Percy, â€œweâ€™re well fucking into Consolidated Statesâ€™ waters now. I think trouble from them is unlikely.â€

Shakes nodded.

Percy placed a steel straight-edge dappled with rust patches down on the chart which showed their proposed course in a hashed line of grease-pencil marks. â€œBarring any unforeseen distractions, this is our planned course. We will be heading into an area that a number of Territorial Authorities claim control over.â€

Shakes reached into his denim vest and withdrew a small pencil and a notebook covered with black and smudged fingerprints. He began to scratch down notes in a fast, unreadable scribble.

â€œThatâ€™s unfortunate, but fucking unavoidable since weâ€™re heading for the mainland port of Stilt City,â€ said Percy.

â€œâ€¦The locals do not call it that,â€ put in Hemi.

Percy waved him off. â€œWe estimate it will take three or four days and nights to get there. Thatâ€™s running slow and deep during the day, and fast on the surface at night with all things fuckinâ€™ nominal.â€

â€œAnd whatâ€™s the plan for the Gnat?â€ Shakes asked.

â€œGenerally, weâ€™ll have you run on the surface during the day. You can shut down the diesel maybe once an hour or so, and weâ€™ll check in on ship-to-ship.â€

â€œThat will also give us a chance to listen for any contacts without being swamped out by the noise of your boat,â€ added Hemi.

â€œAt night, the Gnat is less useful as a decoy, since the Prospect will be on the surface anyway. I think then you can mate up the Gnat and get a meal aboard the Prospect and some sleep â€” at least for a few hours each night.â€

Shakes grinned at the thought of hot meals. â€œWhat happens if someone comes the fuck up on us in the night?â€

â€œWell, weâ€™ll emergency dive to periscope depth, drag you out of your bunk and throw you into your boat, and make sure the Gnat is off before we do a further evasive deep dive. I hate the delay getting the Gnat disconnected will cause, but Iâ€™d hate to deprive you of your fuckinâ€™ precious hot meals.â€

Shakes grinned. â€œNo fucking doubt! Just donâ€™t panic in the heat of the moment and forget that if you dive too deep with the Gnat attached, Iâ€™ll have a bunch of wet scrap metal instead of a boat hanging off the bottom of this rusting fat cigar.â€ He scribbled a few notes. â€œWhat about the Grackle and those fuckinâ€™ guys who were after you? What if they are still following you?â€

â€œI figure since weâ€™re well into another Authorityâ€™s territory now, itâ€™s unlikely they are still coming after us. Itâ€™s one thing to raid a depot just on the other side an Authority line. Itâ€™s another to pursue an unarmed cargo sub across the middle of another Authorityâ€™s area of control. Having said that, did you get any sense while you were at the depot that they knew our destination?â€

â€œI have no idea,â€ said Shakes. â€œIt entirely depends on who they talked to while they were up on the exchange level. I didnâ€™t get to observe any of that.â€

Percy nodded.

â€œWhat about Herschel?â€ asked Hemi. â€œWhen will he be ready to come aboard the Prospect? The Gnat could potentially be a long way off pretty quickly if we get into this situation where you are leading a contact away from the Prospectâ€™s location. It would be nice to have Herschel ready to go find you, if that happens.â€

â€œIs that what you are really thinking Hemi?â€ Percy asked with a grin. â€œOr are you just looking forward to having a fuckinâ€™ fluffy new crew member to take care of?â€

â€œIâ€™m hoping Herschel is acclimated to the Gnat in another day or two. Then we can move him aboard the Prospect,â€ said Shakes.

â€œAlright,â€ said Percy, â€œbring the fucking pigeon over whenever you are ready Captain Shakes. Right now letâ€™s get the Gnat running up on the surface, and get the Prospect further down. I donâ€™t like being this shallow during the day.â€

Shakes gave a fake salute, and went rearward toward the galley to take a refill of coffee with him. He then climbed downward to the deepest part of the Prospect, and then even lower to get back aboard the Gnat.

With the Gnat off and surfaced, the Prospect dove down to 100 meters where Percy was more comfortable with a heavier cover of ocean above her.

âŸ

The rest of the day went as planned. The Prospect moved slowly and silently through the deep, while the Gnat ran just at the surface with its diesel emitting a long brown shit-string of exhaust into the clear ocean air. Shakes had to keep the throttle back on the Gnat to keep pace with the much slower Prospect. At that slower speed, the Gnat was not obtrusively loud, about the same as an average surface cargo ship. That was to their benefit because Authority enforcement craft were less likely to purse a target that sounded like a cargo ship â€” at least during the day â€” since anything on the surface was likely to be moving with the full blessing of the Authority.

Shakes shut down the Gnatâ€™s diesel once every hour or so, and checked in over the ship-to-ship. He had nothing to report but clear weather, modest swells, and open ocean. A white ball of sun pushed its way slowly across a flat white sky, and the two boats droned their way across the curve of the globe. The only thing that changed with the passing time was the sunâ€™s slow fall to the horizon. Shakes had the hatch of the Gnat open and he watched the sun swell up all orange and bloated as it bounced on the perfectly flat table-top off in the west, like it was going to expel a flatulent burst of world-ending fire over the surface of the planet before it was snuffed out by the force of night pressing down on it.

The dark spread slowly from behind, catching up to and overtaking the Gnat. When it did, Captain Percy raised the Prospect to the surface and began night crew rotations, with someone always on the radar and someone always in the lookout ring. A filet knife of a moon came up behind a thick, oppressive haze, its sharp points dulled as if they had been poked one too many times through a heavy fabric or leather.

Shakes ran the Gnat off at some distance for the first half of the night, and then dove and brought it under to mate with the Prospect. This dramatically slowed the Prospectâ€™s speed, but Percy figured this was worth the trade-off of keeping Shakes alert and relatively sane during the day by giving him a chance to sleep while they kept moving. He came on board and ate a couple of large bowls of a hot brown soup Gregory had left simmering on the range, accompanied by thick slices of a stale and grainy bread which Shakes would cover in butter and soak in the soup until each bite softened. He slept for a few hours in one of the Prospectâ€™s padded racks. As the sky lightened in the east, Captain Percy woke him and told him it was time to get the Gnat off.

âŸ

Shakes stumbled to the galley to pick up his morning coffee. There he found Hemi who accompanied him down to the open hatch leading to the Gnat. Shakes disappeared through that hatch and returned holding a small wire cage with a splotchy gray bird. Herschel was sleek and trim, with an unmistakable intelligence to the eyes.

â€œFuckinâ€™ Hemi meet fuckinâ€™ Herschel,â€ said Shakes holding the cage up for Hemi to take while he climbed up out of the Gnat.

Hemi poked a thick finger between the bars and rubbed Herschelâ€™s head gently. â€œCaptain Shakes this bird looks perhaps smarter than me, or yourself.â€

â€œMaybe you should hire him to drive the fuckinâ€™ Gnat for you,â€ said Shakes.

â€œIs this cage not too small for him?â€

â€œThatâ€™s just his travel cage. I have a nice comfy roost installed for him down in the Gnat. You donâ€™t want him to forget where his home is, otherwise he wonâ€™t return there when you release him.â€

â€œCan I let him out of this cage?â€

â€œSure, if you â€” or Percy â€” donâ€™t mind a little pigeon shit around.â€

â€œI believe I shall give this fellow the run of the boat.â€

Shakes handed Hemi a small leather case with tiny papers and a steel band. â€œThis is his leg band. Itâ€™s pretty self-explanatory. Just write your message, attach it, and toss Herschel in the air. Heâ€™ll find the Gnat, if itâ€™s anywhere on the surface within maybe a hundred miles or so.â€

â€œHow do we get him back though?â€ asked Hemi.

â€œWellâ€¦â€ said Shakes scratching his grimy neck with black fingernails. â€œItâ€™s kinda a one-fuckinâ€™-way thing. I have to give him back to you in person. We might be able to get him to fly over to the Prospect from the Gnat if you were within sightâ€¦ and maybe if he knew you had some food.â€

â€œI understand. Itâ€™s a â€˜homingâ€™ pigeon. It only goes home.â€

â€œRight.â€

â€œWell, welcome aboard Herschel. Captain Shakes, have a good run today.â€

â€œI expect to, though Iâ€™ll miss having my copilot with me.â€

5. A Storm

The Gnat was off and the Prospect submerged and cruising at depth before the first molten blob of malevolent red sun percolated up on the horizon. Shakes was running the Gnat hot and loud, standing in the pilotâ€™s chair with his head above the hatch in the wind, trying to blow the bleary sleep out of his eyes. He sucked on a cigarette, but the wind was feeding oxygen to the coal on the end so that it glowed a color not totally unlike that of the sun coming up on the horizon behind him. His cigarette was quickly disappearing into itself. A long shadow of the short sail of the Gnat with his round head on top stretched out in front of him on the slate-colored water.

One-hundred meters below in the Prospect, it was nearly silent as the crew eased into their more relaxed daytime shifts. Captain Percy was in the control room smoking with Bastian. Cassandra had just woken when the boat dove and was making her way with a coffee to the sonar station for the long day watch.

The first few hours passed with dull regularity. Shakes had nothing to report during diesel stops, and by her third cheroot Percy was settling into the comfortable state of mind-blanking boredom that was her most familiar association with life aboard submarines.

Mid-morning of the third day out from the depot, Shakes was shutting down the diesel of the Gnat for the fourth time that morning to check in with the Prospect.

On sonar, Cassandra could heard the Gnatâ€™s diesel putter away to a halt â€” leaving a silent relief in her headphones. As usual, she called up to the control room to let them know the Gnat was shut down for a listening and check-in session. â€œCaptain Percy, the Gnat just went silent.â€

â€œAlright. Thanks Cassandra.â€ Percy called back down to her. Percy took down the ship-to-ship mic. â€œCaptain Shakes â€” the usual: howâ€™re things looking up there?â€

â€œWell, for lack of anything else to report, Iâ€™ll tell you that the weather is thickening up a bit. The haze has really set in, and thereâ€™s a bit of a fuckinâ€™ chop coming on.â€ Percy could hear Shake chewing leaves and sucking saliva as he held the transmit button. â€œIt looks to me like the kind of things that could turn into real weather later.â€

Weather was not generally a concern for Percy, submarines could pass under even the worst weather at depth. But she could not guess at what the Gnat was capable of handling. â€œDoes that give you anything to worry about with the Gnat?â€

â€œNaw,â€ Shakes voice crackled, â€œthe Gnatâ€™s been through the very fucking worst. If it gets bad, Iâ€™ll dive and ride it out underwater. With all this running on the surface, the batteries are always fully topped up so I can stay down for a while.â€

Knowing the Gnat could not dive very deep at all, Percy was unconvinced that this was a solution to big weather, but she also knew Shakes had taken the Gnat back and forth across the wide parts of the oceans many times. She decided to trust his experience. â€œAlright then Captain Shakes. If youâ€¦â€

â€œCaptain Percy!â€ Cassandra interrupted with a shout from sonar, â€œI think Iâ€™ve got a contact.â€

â€œHold on Shakes. We might have a contact. Donâ€™t start your diesel.â€ Percy hung up the mic and slid down the ladder.

Cassandra had her eyes closed and was concentrating intently on the sounds in her headset. She had the mics pointed towards the Prospectâ€™s hard rear starboard quarter, and the signal strength indicator gauge was nodding weakly just a bit above the pin. â€œIt feels like Iâ€™m only on the edge of the signal. They might be directly behind us.â€

â€œBastian,â€ Percy called up to him, â€œthrottle down. Stop the props. Cassandra needs to hear whatâ€™s behind us.â€

A moment later the perennially resonant electric motor sounds died away. Cassandra turned the sonar mics back to face the dead stern of the boat. The signal strength indicator immediately shot up to a definite contact. â€œAbsolutely confirmed Captain Percy. I can hear the engine in the water. Sounds like another diesel.â€

Percy looked at the signal strength dial and knew immediately that the contact had subversively crept closer to them under the sound of the Gnatâ€™s diesel when it was running, and then even a bit closer than that by aligning themselves dead astern of the Prospect where Cassandra could not hear well over the sound of the Prospectâ€™s own prop turning. Based on the signal strength indicator, the contact was likely far closer than Percy was comfortable with now â€” maybe twenty nautical miles. â€œFuck,â€ was all she said.

She climbed up to the control room and got Shakes back on the ship-to-ship. â€œDefinitely a fuckinâ€™ contact Shakes. Now itâ€™s your turn. Fire up the Gnat and see if you can lead them off and away from us. Letâ€™s see if this scheme of ours works!â€

â€œAbsolutely! Motherfuckâ€¦â€ The end of his oath was cut off by the whining start of the Gnatâ€™s diesel engine which came blaring over the ship-to-ship radio for a moment before Shakes took his thumb off the transmit button.

Percy flipped on the red night lighting. â€œBastian â€” donâ€™t move the fuckinâ€™ boat. Donâ€™t trim anything or let her make any fuckinâ€™ sounds at all.â€

â€œDead-silent-crypt drift, got it Captain,â€ said Bastian.

Percy slid down to the sonar compartment again and tapped Cassandra on the shoulder. â€œStay on both the new contact and the Gnat Cassandra. Iâ€™m going to wake Hemi.â€ Percy disappeared down the ladder to crew quarters and returned a minute later with Hemiâ€™s big form following her up from below. He was still pulling on his tweed jacket and fixing his spectacles while he sat at the sonar station and put on the second headset.

Cassandra looked at him, and pointed at the signal strength gauge and the bearing without saying anything. Hemi nodded while listening.

After a minute, Percy broke the silence. â€œWell, Hemiâ€¦ is that our fucking creepy sub with the fuckinâ€™ ram?â€

Hemi sighed. â€œIt is â€” the Grackle. Absolutely. The ram gives it a distinctive and entirely identifiable hull noise.â€

â€œFuck me!â€ said Percy. â€œSo much for the theory that they wouldnâ€™t fuckinâ€™ follow us this far into another Authorityâ€™s territory. Ah fuck. It doesnâ€™t matter â€” what matters is our current situation. Next order of business you two: are they following Shakes away from us.â€

Hemi took over the sonar directional control wheel from Cassandra and made some slight adjustments to center the signal. He flipped some switches to engage filters, and a moment later turned them off again. â€œYou see Cassandra,â€ he explained pointing to the switches and dials, â€œwith these filters engaged I can better hear the Gnat, and with them disengaged it is easier to focus on the pursuing sub.â€

She nodded.

After a few minutes of listening Hemi reported to Percy: â€œitâ€¦ seems like it is working Sylvia. The Grackle is definitely following Shakes. Andâ€¦â€ He paused for a moment to continue listening, â€œShakes seems to be able to stay well ahead of them.â€ He pointed to the mic directional indicator. â€œThey are already ten degrees off our course, and moving away quickly.â€

â€œThatâ€™s fucking excellent Hemi,â€ Percy said.

â€œCanâ€™t they like, shoot at Captain Shakes or something?â€ asked Cassandra.

â€œIt is difficult to hit such a small fast-moving target as the Gnat with a torpedo. Though the Gnatâ€™s engine is so loud that it is doubtful Shakes would hear an incoming torpedo. Hopefully he is experienced enough to make random course changes every five miles or so to make aiming a torpedo more challengingâ€¦â€ Hemi looked doubtful.

â€œWell, keep the fuck on them,â€ said Percy. â€œLet me know if anything changesâ€¦ or what the final result is.â€ She stuck a cheroot between her teeth and climbed the ladder to the control room.

â€œCassandra, keep tracking them,â€ said Hemi. He stood up, still wearing the second sonar headset, and turned to lean over the navigation table. He measured the angle of the bearing to the contacts off their current position marked on the chart, and then drew a line marking Shakes and the pursuing subâ€™s course. Listening carefully to what the sonar was picking up in his headset, he could estimate Grackle and Gnatâ€™s distance from the Prospect.

He and Cassandra tracked the two sound sources like this for over an hour. Then he stood to his full height and stretched. He took off the headset and hung it on the peg, and patted Cassandra on the shoulder before climbing up to the control room.

â€œShakes and the Grackle are already far off and moving further out of range. I can no longer estimate distance on the sonar,â€ said Hemi. â€œWhat is the end-game in this maneuver?â€ Shakes cannot run forever.â€

â€œWell, hopefully that fuckinâ€™ pursuing sub realizes they are on the wrong target at a good distance away from us. Then, presumably, they will leave off chasing Shakes and turn around to try to reacquire us here where they lost us. We will, of course, be long gone by then.â€

â€œSo now would be the time for us to make a course change.â€

â€œIndeed. But my question for you, Hemi, is: how do we find Shakes again? You think you can raise him with that fuckinâ€™ bird?â€

â€œI think Herschel will prove better than trying to reconnect with Shakes via radio. To get him on the radio, we both have to be on the surface at the same time, and he has to have his diesel off. Not to mention the radio could be monitored. We can let Herschel go with a message and dive immediately. The message would be extremely unlikely to be intercepted.â€

â€œOK. Weâ€™ll surface tonight, and you can send the pigeon out after Shakes then.â€

Cassandra kept listening to the sonar for another half hour, occasionally reporting that she thought she could still hear the Gnat or the Grackle when the conditions were favorable. At that point Percy decided it was time to leave, and had Bastian throttle the electric motors up to 15 knots. They moved off on a southerly course that Percy selected at random to move them away from the area.

The rest of the hours of the day ticked by with nothing to break the monotony and no changes to make other than occasional minor adjustments to the trim of the boat. Whereas earlier Cassandra had been cursing the noise of the Gnatâ€™s engine polluting the water, now she found she missed it. Somehow it had been comforting to know Shakes was up there on the surface. Not to mention that his hourly check-ins were at least a way to mark time and shift her attention. Now they were down in this dark cold pit of water, blind and alone, and it began to feel like they were doomed to remain like this until the end of their days.

âŸ

Hours later, when the clock said it should be early evening on the surface of the world, Cassandraâ€™s eyes were bleary and drooping as she stared blankly at the sonar console. Captain Percy and Hemi were having a discussion behind her in the sonar compartment about whether it was time to surface and begin their nighttime run.

â€œHowâ€™s the charge on the batteries Hemi?â€ Percy asked.

â€œOK, but getting low. We are at maybe 20 percent capacity.â€

â€œSo, we could stay under maybe another four or five hours at a creep.â€

â€œYes. We took a big chunk out of the batteries by leaving the area where we contacted the Grackle at such a high speed.â€

â€œI know, but strategically, putting on some fuckinâ€™ distance was the right thing to do.â€

â€œI do not disagree,â€ said Hemi.

â€œSo when should we surface? We definitely want to run the diesels and put a charge back on the batteries, but it opens us up as a radar contact for those fuckers following us. They could easily still be within range to detect us on radar.â€

â€œAnd if they do, the whole move with Shakes would have been wasted.â€

â€œFuckinâ€™ right. So, do you got a recommendation for me?â€

Hemi turned to Cassandra and tapped her on the shoulder. â€œAny contacts on sonar Cassandra?â€

She pulled back a headphone. â€œNothingâ€¦ mechanical. But the background noise of the ocean has changed Hemi. It soundsâ€¦ weirdly energetic.â€

â€œHmm.â€ Hemi picked up the other headset and made some adjustments. He listened for a moment and pulled the headset off. â€œWell, that complicates things. Seems like we drove right into that storm Shakes was predicting.â€

â€œFuck,â€ said Percy.

â€œOhhhâ€¦â€ said Cassandra to herself, â€œso thatâ€™s what a churned up surface sounds like.â€ She filed away in her mind another almost-magical aspect of sonar. â€œBut Hemi, I donâ€™t feel any storm affecting the Prospect?â€

â€œEven bad storms do not stir the water this deep.â€

â€œOn the surface though,â€ said Percy, â€œitâ€™s another fucking matter.â€

â€œâ€¦I hope Captain Shakes is alright.â€ Cassandra muttered a little blessing for his well-being.

â€œHow bad does that storm sound Hemi?â€ Percy asked.

â€œSignificant, I would say. There could be ten meter waves up there.â€

â€œThatâ€™s the kind of weather weâ€™re better off staying under.â€

â€œAt least while we still have any battery left,â€ Hemi agreed.

â€œNormally, thatâ€™s the obvious move. But we need to be thinking ahead as well: staying down now could force us to the surface in daylight with no charge at all on the battery. We could end up a helpless target. If we go up now we can get the batteries charged up with very little chance of being found.â€

â€œRunning on the surface in the storm does provide a lot of cover â€” the radar will be swamped and the ocean makes enough noise to cover our running dieselsâ€¦ But it could also swamp us or crack the Prospectâ€™s spine.â€

â€œSheâ€™s a strong fuckinâ€™ boat Hemi, and with good pilots I think she can handle it. Letâ€™s prep to surface.â€

âŸ

Hemi and Captain Percy climbed up to the control room. Bastian and Owen sat in the control seats watching the unmoving gauges with bored and sleepy eyes.

â€œWe are going to surface,â€ said Hemi. â€œAnd there is a serious storm up there. Owen, I am going to sit in that plane control chair. I need you to go down to the navigation/sonar compartment and get ready to blow the main ballast tanks.â€

â€œYou want to do an emergency blow?â€ Owen asked.

Owen stood, and Hemi slipped his bulky form around him and down into the tight fit of the planes control chair. â€œNot a full blow. On my signal I just want you to open the high pressure air into the main ballast for a few seconds. I want to pop the boat up onto the surface. If we use the normal low-pressure system to ease up, there is too much of a chance for the intakes to be swamped in these seas. You all understand the procedure?â€

Owen and Bastian nodded. Owen slipped down the ladder to the sonar compartment and they could hear him opening the toolbox that held the emergency blow wrench.

â€œOK Bastian, give us a little more throttle. I am adjusting the planes for some up-angle.â€

The bow of the boat rose slowly ahead of them, and Percy, being the only one standing, leaned into the angle. She found her pack of cheroots tucked into the wall joists, and pulled one out to light it. Bastian slipped a cigarette from his shirt pocket and lit it off Percyâ€™s coal.

â€œHemi, another degree on the bow, I think,â€ said Percy.

Hemi turned the plane control wheel slightly, and the boat eased to a somewhat steeper angle. He made some small adjustments on the trim tank control panel to make the front of the boat a bit more buoyant so the motors did not have to put quite so much energy into lifting the bow.

â€œI am going to come level at just about ten meters, then we will have Owen blow air into the main ballast tanks.â€ Hemi kept his eyes locked on the depth gauge, watching it crawl slowly back around towards the zero mark as the boat rose. Just as it passed the ten meter mark, Hemi turned the plane control wheel and the bow of the boat came down to level. At this shallower depth, the boat took on the motion from the waves on the surface, slowly listing from one side to the other by ten degrees or so. â€œOK!â€ Hemi yelled down to Owen. â€œOpen the air into the main ballast Owen!â€

Percy punched the emergency blow alarm, to be sure that this time everyone on the boat was aware they were performing a dangerous maneuver.

From below they heard the squeak of the turning valve, and a loud hiss. Air rushed through the pipes below them and out into the ballast. Hemi started counting to himself. There was a pause where nothing happened and then they all felt the upward acceleration of the Prospect lifting.

Hemiâ€™s count hit five. â€œClose it down Owen!â€

The hiss stopped, but the upward motion did not. Percy wrapped her fingers in the leather strap hanging over her head. They rode the force of the expanding air upwards for a few seconds and then the boat went weightless for a moment as it reached the surface. They could feel their stomachs rise within, and Hemi and Bastianâ€™s knuckles went white as they tightened their grip on the control wheels.

The depth gauge landed firmly on its zero pin and sat there. The boat rolled slowly and heavily with the surface swell.
